{{Spanish name|Lara|Santoya}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Erislandy Lara | image = Erislandy Lara.jpg | caption = Lara vs. [[Grady Brewer|Brewer]], 2010 | realname = Erislandy Lara Santoya | nickname = {{plainlist| *''El Oro de Guantanamo'' *The American Dream }} | weight = [[Light middleweight]] | height = 5 ft 9 in<ref name=stats2018>[[Showtime Championship Boxing]] tale of the tape prior to the [[Jarrett Hurd]] fight.</ref> | reach = 75+1/2 in<ref name=stats2018/> | nationality = {{plainlist| *Cuban *American }} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|4|11}} | birth_place = [[Guantanamo]], Cuba | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 30 | wins = 25 | KO = 14 | losses = 3 | draws = 2 | no contests = | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Men's [[amateur boxing]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{CUB}} }} {{MedalCompetition | [[World Amateur Boxing Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalGold | [[2005 World Amateur Boxing Championships|2005 Mianyang]] | Welterweight}} {{MedalCompetition | [[Central American and Caribbean Games]]}} {{MedalGold | [[2006 Central American and Caribbean Games|2006 Cartagena]] | [[Boxing at the 2006 Central American and Caribbean Games|Welterweight]]}} {{MedalCompetition | [[Boxing World Cup|World Cup]]}} {{MedalSilver | [[2005 Boxing World Cup|2005 Moscow]] | Welterweight}} }}
'''Erislandy Lara Santoya''' (born April 11, 1983) is a Cuban-American<ref>Keidel, Jason (July 11, 2014). [http://sports.cbslocal.com/2014/07/11/cbs-local-sports-qa-erislandy-lara-chopped-canelo-alvarezs-pride-to-get-the-fight/ "CBS Local Sports Q&A: Erislandy Lara 'Chopped' Alvarez's Pride To Get The Fight"]. ''[[CBS Sports]]''. [[CBS]]. Retrieved January 12, 2018.</ref> [[professional boxer]]. He held the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[light middleweight]] title from 2014 to 2018 (promoted to [[WBA (Super)|Super champion]] in 2016), and the [[International Boxing Organization|IBO]] light middleweight title from 2015 to 2018. As of April 2018, he is ranked as the world's third best active light middleweight by ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'' magazine, [[BoxRec]], and [[Transnational Boxing Rankings Board]].
Lara is widely regarded as one of the most technically skilled fighters in boxing today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesweetscience.com/news/articles-frontpage/20195-the-underappreciated-boxing-brilliance-of-erislandy-lara|title=The Underappreciated Boxing Brilliance of Erislandy Lara|author=Kelsey McCarson|work=The Sweet Science}}</ref> He was captain of the Cuban national [[amateur boxing|amateur]] team, winning a gold medal in the [[welterweight]] division at the [[2005 World Amateur Boxing Championships|2005 World Championships]] as well as three consecutive Cuban national championships from 2005 to 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenboypromotions.com/fighters/lara-erislandy/ |title=Erislandy Lara |work=goldenboypromotions.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707095505/http://www.goldenboypromotions.com/fighters/lara-erislandy/ |archivedate=2015-07-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Amateur career== In 2003 and 2004, Lara lost four times against two-time world champion [[Lorenzo Aragon]].
In 2005 after Aragon stepped down, Lara bested his countryman [[Yudel Johnson|Yudel Jhonson Cedeno]] repeatedly and was sent to the world championships. There he avenged an earlier loss to Russian [[Andrey Balanov]], beat American [[Boyd Melson]], upset top favorite and Olympic champion [[Bakhtiyar Artayev]] (31–22), and won Gold against [[Magomed Nurutdinov]] (BLR).
Lara has lost twice to another Kazakh, [[Bakhyt Sarsekbayev]]. In their only meeting, Lara beat American world champion [[Demetrius Andrade]] 9–4.
===Boxing World Cup=== *'''[[2005 Boxing World Cup|2005]]''' in [[Moscow, Russia]] (welterweight) **Defeated [[Manon Boonjumnong]] (Thailand) 21–9 **Defeated Stefan Dragomir (Romania) RSC–3 **Defeated Bakhyt Sarsekbayev (Kazakhstan) 39–33 **Lost to Andrey Balanov (Russia) 21–36
==Defection from Cuba== Erislandy Lara was considered a favorite to win the gold medal at the [[2008 Beijing Olympic Games]]. However, in 2007, Lara and [[Guillermo Rigondeaux]] defected from Cuba during the [[Pan American Games]] in [[Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]]. Some weeks later, he was caught by Brazilian authorities and returned to Cuba where he was banned from practicing boxing indefinitely.
In 2008, Lara attempted a second defection, this time on a speed boat to Mexico. Lara was successful and made his way to [[Hamburg, Germany]], where he joined former Olympic champions [[Odlanier Solis]], [[Yan Barthelemy]], and [[Yuriorkis Gamboa]] in the Arena Box-Promotion stable.
==Professional career==
===Early fights=== On January 1, 2009, Erislandy Lara made his ESPN debut and scored a first-round [[Knockout|TKO]] against Rodrigo Aguiar. Lara's following fight came on February 20, 2009, against Keith Gross. Lara dropped Gross with a left hand, but Gross beat the count on wobbly legs. Lara continued unleashing combinations to the head and body. A left uppercut finished the fight within round one. On May 2, 2009, on the Pacquiao vs. Hatton undercard, Lara faced Chris Gray. Lara won the fight via unanimous decision. On May 22, 2009, Lara faced aging Edwin Vazquez. Lara finished the fight with good combinations, prompting the referee to stop the fight in round four. On that same night, fellow Cuban boxer [[Guillermo Rigondeaux]] made his pro debut, which he also won via referee stoppage in the third round. After beating Edwin Vazquez, Lara went on to win nine straight fights punctuated by four consecutive first-round knockout victories.
=== Career from 2011–2012 ===
==== Lara vs. Molina, Williams ==== On March 25, 2011, at [[Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas|The Cosmopolitan]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Lara fought [[Carlos Molina (Mexican boxer)|Carlos Molina]] to a ten-round majority draw. Lara started by frequently targeting Molina's body with the left uppercut when Molina would attempt to close the distance. Early on Molina seemed to predict and nullify much of Lara's attempted one-two combinations. Although Lara had trouble connecting his signature straight left hand initially, he found the distance by the middle rounds, began to mix in short hooks to the head, and blocked most of Molina's constant body work. Molina, on the other hand, was rarely able to find Lara's head throughout the entire fight. Relying on looping punches, Molina stayed close and took advantage of the clinches to land to the body. Visibly fatigued, Molina developed a cut under his left eye near the beginning of the ninth round as Lara landed a hard, clean straight left hand and pushed the pace. Molina's higher output and pressure were favored by one judge while Lara's cleaner, sharper output and defense went largely unnoticed by ringside commentators. The final scorecards read: 95–95, 95–95, and 97–93 in favor of Molina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-carlos-molina-ends-majority-draw--37429 |title=Erislandy Lara, Carlos Molina Ends in a Majority Draw - Boxing News |publisher=Boxingscene.com |date=2011-03-26 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/compubox-punch-stats-molina-edge-over-lara--37444|title=CompuBox Punch Stats: Molina Has The Edge Over Lara|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref>
Lara fought former [[WBO]] welterweight champion [[Paul Williams (boxer)|Paul Williams]] on July 9, 2011, in [[Atlantic City]] where he lost a majority decision. Judges Don Givens (116–114) and Hilton Whitaker II (115–114) both favored Williams, while Al Bennett scored it even at 114–114.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=6571236 |title=Paul Williams looks to rebound from knockout in bout against Erislandy Lara - ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=2011-05-20 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref> Most boxing analysts and fans believed that Lara clearly won the fight and had been unfairly judged. Lara was able to land hard, clean left hands throughout the fight while maintaining superb defense. Williams appeared hurt in the later rounds but did, however, keep up a high output of punches despite their relative ineffectiveness. [[CompuBox]] recorded Lara landing 49 percent of his power punches compared to 21 percent by Williams. Lara also landed seven more jabs and 17 more power punches than Williams, despite the near two-fold activity by Williams.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.boxingscene.com/forums/view.php?pg=williams-lara-compubox |title=Paul Williams vs. Erislandy Lara - CompuBox Stats |website=Boxingscene.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref> Consequently, the [[New Jersey State Athletic Control Board]] suspended all three judges, and Lara received his first loss as a professional fighter in a highly controversial fashion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/6767425/paul-williams-erislandy-lara-judges-suspended-new-jersey-state-athletic-control-board |title=Paul Williams-Erislandy Lara judges suspended by New Jersey State Athletic Control Board |website=Espn.go.com |date=2011-07-13 |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsgrid.com/boxing/an-incompetent-decision-hbo-announcers-enraged-by-refuse-to-accept-boxing-result/ |title=Williams-Lara Result Upsets HBO Broadcasters |publisher=SportsGrid |date=2011-07-10 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref>
==== Lara vs. Hearns, Martirosyan ==== On April 20, 2012, Lara made his comeback to the ring after nine months to fight [[Ronald Hearns]] for the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] light middleweight semi-final eliminator spot at the [[Beau Rivage (Mississippi)|Beau Rivage]] casino resort in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-ronald-hearns-battle-on-february-11th--47533|title=Erislandy Lara-Ronald Hearns To Battle on February 11th?|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-discusses-bout-with-ronald-hearns--47739|title=Erislandy Lara Discusses The Bout With Ronald Hearns|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref> The fight, which was scheduled to go ten rounds, simply lasted one minute and 34 seconds as Lara delivered an impressive TKO in the first round. Referee Keith Hughes decided to stop the fight after Lara had sent Hearns to the canvas once with a clean left hook that required count and immediately after delivered two fast combinations (one of which also required count) that seemed to be enough to overwhelm Hearns who seconds before the stop by the referee appeared to be defenseless upon Lara's final combination.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/laras-lightning-ko-steals-taylors-main-event-thunder--52017|title=Lara's Lightning KO Steals Taylor's Main Event Thunder|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref>
On November 10, 2012, at the [[Wynn Las Vegas|Wynn Resort]] in Las Vegas, Lara faced [[Vanes Martirosyan]], who was undeafeted at the time and known for his amateur wins over [[Andre Berto]], [[Austin Trout]], and [[Timothy Bradley]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/vanes-signed-contract-three-weeks-ago-waits-on-lara--56241|title=Vanes Signed Contract Three Weeks Ago, Waits on Lara|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/schaefer-lara-signs-face-vanes-on-november-10th--56244|title=Schaefer: Lara Signs To Face Vanes on November 10th|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref> Lara connected on 42 percent of his power punches (40/95) while Martirosyan landed 16 percent of his (27/167) and only 6 jabs throughout the entire fight, according to CompuBox. Lara outlanded Martirosyan in overall punches, 74 to 33.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://compuboxonline.com/compubox-stats-martirosyan-td-8-lara/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 25, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160404074603/http://compuboxonline.com/compubox-stats-martirosyan-td-8-lara/ |archivedate=April 4, 2016 }}</ref> After a clash of heads resulted in a gash over Martirosyan's left eye in the ninth round, the ringside doctor waved off the fight. The referee ordered the judges to score the final 26 seconds of the bout, which resulted in a technical draw (87–84 in favor of Lara, 86–85 in favor of Martirosyan, and 86–86). Dave Moretti was responsible for the tied scorecard and judged the ninth round as 10–10, disagreeing with the other two judges who scored the final 26 seconds as 10–9 for Lara.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2012/11/10/3629784/martirosyan-vs-lara-results-headbutt-draw-hbo-boxing |title=Martirosyan vs Lara results: Headbutt results in technical draw after nine rounds |publisher=Bad Left Hook |date= |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/ariza-puzzled-with-judge-who-scored-erislandy-lara--59227|title=Ariza Puzzled With Judge Who Scored For Erislandy Lara|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref>
=== WBA light middleweight champion ===
==== Lara vs. Angulo, Trout ==== On June 8, 2013, at the [[Home Depot Center]] in [[Carson, California]], Lara received the first two knockdowns of his professional career en route to earning a TKO victory over Mexico's [[Alfredo Angulo]] along with the [[interim championship|interim]] [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] light middleweight title.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/angulo-vs-lara-co-headline-maidana-lopez-card--63848|title=Angulo vs. Lara To Co-Headline Maidana-Lopez Card|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref> Angulo's left hook was vicious as he rushed in, guarded and low. Lara, in return, was able to utilize zigzag formations and vary the speed of his movement to bait Angulo's aggression. However, Lara struggled with the aggression of Angulo at times and was put on the canvas in rounds 4 and 9 courtesy of Angulo’s vaunted left hook.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=96dGTSQREWc |title=Erislandy Lara vs Alfredo Angulo - Film Study |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2014-05-10 |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref> Lara landed 56 percent of his power punches while Angulo landed 31 percent of his, according to CompuBox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://compuboxonline.com/compubox-stats-lara-ko-10-angulo/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=January 12, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309085501/http://compuboxonline.com/compubox-stats-lara-ko-10-angulo/ |archivedate=March 9, 2016 }}</ref> The fight was stopped in round ten when Angulo refused to continue after a straight left hand by Lara caused swelling around his right eye. Angulo's injury was later revealed to be a broken orbital bone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2013/6/9/4410702/angulo-vs-lara-results-erislandy-lara-gets-off-canvas-twice-stops|title=Angulo vs Lara results: Erislandy Lara gets off canvas twice, stops Angulo in 10th round|author=Scott Christ|work=Bad Left Hook}}</ref>
On December 7, 2013, Lara fought [[Austin Trout]] at [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/lara-vs-trout-regular-wba-title-stake--70830|title=Lara vs. Trout To Have "Regular" WBA Title at Stake|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref> Considered the favorite to win, Trout had recently beaten [[Miguel Cotto]]. Lara, however, put on a dominant performance as he immediately nullified Trout’s offense using deft footwork and clean punching. In outclassing Trout, Lara scored a knockdown in round eleven via straight left hand. Trout was hurt for the remainder of the round as Lara pressed the action. Lara cruised to the unanimous decision (117–111, 117–111, and 118–109) and retained his interim WBA light middleweight title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/182397-erislandy-lara-drops-dominates-austin-trout-to-unanimous-decision|title=Erislandy Lara drops, dominates Austin Trout to unanimous decision|author=ringtv|date=8 December 2013|work=Ring TV|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626114127/http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/182397-erislandy-lara-drops-dominates-austin-trout-to-unanimous-decision|archivedate=26 June 2015|df=}}</ref>
====Lara vs. Álvarez==== Lara fought [[Saúl Álvarez]] on July 12, 2014, at the [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]] in a non-title match. Lara's WBA light middleweight title was not on the line as the fight took place at a 155-pound catchweight, and both fighters weighed in at precisely 155 pounds. Álvarez rehydrated to 171 pounds while Lara came into the ring at 166 pounds. In a very close and competitive fight that went to a split decision, Álvarez came out on top with the two judges scoring 115–113 in favor of each fighter and the final judge scoring 117–111 in favor of Álvarez.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2127892-canelo-affirms-superstar-status-with-split-decision-win-over-erislandy-lara |title=Canelo Affirms superstar status with split decision over Erislandy Lara - Bleacher Report |publisher=bleacherreport.com |date=2014-07-13 |accessdate=2014-07-14}}</ref> The final scorecard was controversial as many observers considered it far too wide. According to CompuBox, Lara landed 55 jabs to nine from Álvarez, who landed the jab at a five percent connect rate. Álvarez managed to land 88 power punches (73 to the body) while Lara landed 53 power punches all to the head. Lara's clean punching along with his defense and movement were weighed against Álvarez's effective aggressiveness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/347705-alvarez-beats-lara-but-the-debate-on-who-really-won-continues |title=Alvarez beats Lara but the debate on who ‘really’ won continues - Ring TV |website=Ringtv.craveonline.com |date=2014-07-13 |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref> Lara came out in dominant fashion, utilizing a stick-and-move style and capturing the early rounds. Álvarez was later able to hammer away to the body when he had Lara on the ropes but never adjusted to Lara's one-two combinations. Lara's lead hand played a huge role in this combination's effectiveness, but his output dropped in the middle rounds. Álvarez was able to cut Lara with a lead left uppercut in the seventh round.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqlazGcaP8U|title=Erislandy Lara vs Canelo - Lara Film Study|date=6 October 2014|work=YouTube}}</ref> Although the decision remains controversial, any talk of a rematch in the future was dismissed by [[Oscar De La Hoya]] who went on to say, "No one wants a rematch."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2014/jul/13/oscar-de-la-hoya-wont-explore-canelo-alvarez-remat/ |title=Oscar De La Hoya Wont Explore Canelo Alvarez Rematch - Las Vegas Sun |publisher=lasvegassun.com |date=2014-07-13 |accessdate=2014-07-14}}</ref> This fight resulted in Lara's second professional loss.
====Lara vs. Smith==== On December 12, 2014, at the [[Alamodome]] in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], Lara showcased his ability to move in range to punch and then swiftly escape without taking damage against [[Ishe Smith]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/lara-smith-play-december-12-san-antonio--83644|title=Lara-Smith in Play For December 12 in San Antonio|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-us}}</ref> Lara consistently landed the straight left hand after “blinding” or “occupying” Smith’s guard with the lead hand. Lara would move in a forward direction towards Smith and escape in a linear direction, oftentimes sidestepping, while landing the one-two combination. This lateral movement was enhanced by Lara’s wide boxing stance, which also enhanced Lara’s punching power. Lara was frequently able to turn Smith into additional punches by stepping around Smith’s lead foot, thus enabling Lara to set traps.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W7t8D2geXic|title=★ Erislandy Lara vs Ishe Smith - Film Study ★|date=6 February 2015|work=YouTube}}</ref> Lara dominated the fight and successfully defended his WBA (Regular) light middleweight title by unanimous decision with the scorecards reading: 119–109, 119–109, and 117–111.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2298657-erislandy-lara-vs-ishe-smith-winner-scorecard-and-analysis|title=Erislandy Lara vs. Ishe Smith: Winner, Scorecard and Analysis|author=Joseph Zucker|work=Bleacher Report}}</ref>
=== WBA and IBO light middleweight champion ===
==== Lara vs. Rodríguez, Zaveck ==== On June 12, 2015, Lara defended his WBA (Regular) light middleweight title and won the vacant [[International Boxing Organization|IBO]] light middleweight title against [[Delvin Rodríguez]] at the [[UIC Pavilion]] in [[Chicago]]. In a technical exhibition, Lara's exquisite timing and fast hands allowed him to out land Rodríguez 233 to 63 in total punches and connect on 62 percent of his power punches. Lara was able to score a knockdown in round six via straight left hand. In a virtual shutout, Lara earned a unanimous decision with all three judges agreeing 120–107.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/13069163/erislandy-lara-earns-unanimous-decision-win-delvin-rodriguez-keep-junior-middleweight-title|title=Erislandy Lara earns unanimous-decision win over Delvin Rodriguez to keep junior middleweight title|work=ESPN.com}}</ref>
On November 25, 2015, Lara defended his WBA and IBO light middleweight titles against [[Jan Zaveck]] in Hialeah, Florida. On a wetted canvas due to prior heavy rain, Lara began by walking down Zaveck who was relying on wide punches. Lara continued to stay in the pocket and countered Zaveck, halting his aggression. At the end of round two, Zaveck was hurt after Lara split his jab with a clean left hand. Lara landed a straight left hand at the start of round three followed by a series of combinations punctuating with an uppercut at which point Zaveck put his hand out, turned away, and refused to continue. Zaveck appeared to be in quite a lot of pain after the fight, which was stopped 41 seconds into round three.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/14226952/erislandy-lara-beats-jan-zaveck-defend-wba-super-welterweight-title |title=Erislandy Lara beats Jan Zaveck to defend junior middleweight title |website=Espn.go.com |date=2015-11-26 |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2015/11/25/9803052/pbc-on-espn-results-erislandy-lara-dominates-stops-jan-zaveck-in-3 |title=PBC on ESPN results: Erislandy Lara dominates, stops Jan Zaveck in 3 |publisher=Bad Left Hook |date= |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref>
====Lara vs. Martirosyan II==== It was announced that Lara would be defending his titles in a rematch from 2012 with [[Vanes Martirosyan]], which ended in a draw. The fight was to take place as part of a triple header also including the Charlo twins and [[Austin Trout]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sho.com/sports/fights/961/lara-vs-martirosyan|title=LARA VS. MARTIROSYAN|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref> The fight took place on May 21, 2016 in Las Vegas. On fight night, Lara unofficially weighed 160.5 pounds while Martirosyan came in at 170 pounds. Martirosyan spent much of the fight attempting to impose his strength and body work on Lara. As a result, Martirosyan inadvertently landed multiple low blows until he was deducted a point in the eleventh round. The bout was also plagued by head clashes much like during their previous encounter. In the early rounds both men stayed in perfect range, each relying on their own reflexes and quick transitions from defense to offense. Lara found openings for his sharp punches. As the fight progressed, he was more mobile and dictated the pace, outmaneuvering Martirosyan while managing to land flashy 1-2-1 combinations. After seizing ring generalship, [[Paulie Malignaggi]] noted Lara's "fluid footwork" and a resemblance to [[Pernell Whitaker]] as he often ducked low and displayed tricky pivot moves to evade Martirosyan's punches by inches. Lara landed 63 jabs and 60% of his power punches to Martirosyan's 16 jabs and 23% power punch connect rate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2016/5/22/11735124/lara-vs-martirosyan-ii-results-erislandy-lara-wins-decision-to-retain |title=Lara vs Martirosyan II results: Erislandy Lara wins decision to retain WBA title |publisher=Bad Left Hook |date=2016-05-22 |accessdate=2016-06-21}}</ref> The fight averaged 491,000 viewers and peaked at 545,000 viewers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingnews24.com/2016/05/lara-martirosyan-averages-491k-viewers-showtime/|title=Lara-Martirosyan 2 averages 491K viewers on Showtime » Boxing News|date=2016-05-25|work=Boxing News 24|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== Lara vs. Foreman ==== Early reports on November 30, 2016, stated that there were talks of Lara to defend his WBA and IBO titles against former WBA light middleweight champion [[Yuri Foreman]] (34-2, 10 KOs). Lara's team was also in talks with [[Luis Collazo]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ringtv.com/475457-erislandy-lara-yuri-foreman-close-deal-jan-fight/|title=ERISLANDY LARA AND YURI FOREMAN CLOSE TO DEAL FOR JAN. FIGHT|last=|first=|date=November 30, 2016|website=The Ring|publisher=|access-date=December 1, 2016}}</ref> It was confirmed that the fight against Foreman would headline the Premier Boxing Champions on January 13, 2017. The fight was held at the Hialeah Park Racing and Casino in Miami, Florida, in front of a largely Cuban crowd.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ringnews24.com/2016/12/14/erislandy-lara-defend-yuri-foreman/|title=Erislandy Lara to defend against Yuri Foreman|date=2016-12-14|website=Ring News 24|access-date=2016-12-14}}</ref> Foreman was knocked down in round three. Upon closer inspection, the fall could easily have been ruled a slip. Lara won the fight after delivering a knockout in the fourth round via left uppercut. Although Foreman beat the count, he was on unsteady legs after multiple attempts to get back up. The referee promptly waved off the bout. In the post-fight interview, Lara expressed his desire to finally face off with unified middleweight titlist [[Gennady Golovkin]] and rematch [[lineal championship|lineal]] middleweight titlist [[Canelo Álvarez]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ringtv.com/480465-erislandy-lara-stops-yuri-foreman-four-rounds/|title=Erislandy Lara stops Yuri Foreman in four rounds - The Ring|date=2017-01-14|newspaper=The Ring|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/wba-champ-lara-targets-ggg-canelo-389711|title=WBA champ Lara targets GGG and Canelo • Boxing News|date=2017-01-14|newspaper=Boxing News|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-15}}</ref> The fight averaged 547,000 viewers on Spike TV and peaked at 707,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-yuri-foreman-card-generates-547000-viewers--112835|title=Erislandy Lara-Yuri Foreman Card Generates 547,000 Viewers|last=|first=|date=January 20, 2017|website=Boxing Scene|publisher=|access-date=January 21, 2017}}</ref>
==== Lara vs. Gausha ==== It was confirmed on August 24, 2017, by Ringtv that Lara would fight former Olympian [[Terrell Gausha]] (20-0, 9 KOs) as part of a super welterweight triple header on October 14, 2017, at the Barclays Center in New York City. Other fights on the card would include [[Jermell Charlo]]'s mandatory title defence against top prospect [[Erickson Lubin]] and [[Jarrett Hurd]] defending his IBF title against former champion [[Austin Trout]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ringtv.com/505587-jermell-charlo-erickson-lubin-lara-gausha-title-tilts-agreed/|title=Jermell Charlo-Erickson Lubin tops 154-pound title tripleheader on Oct. 14 - The Ring|date=2017-08-24|work=The Ring|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-US}}</ref> In front of 7,643, Lara knocked down Gausha en-route to a 12-round unanimous decision to retain his world titles. Lara used his accurate jab and left hand putting on a clinic winning with the scorecards 116-111 and 117-110 twice in his favour. Lara connected with a left hook followed by a left straight, which floored Gausha in the fourth round. Lara landed 121 of 528 punches (23%), while Gausha connected with 77 of 329 (23%), which appeared to do little damage. Lara praised his opponent in the post-fight interview, "We want to give a lot of credit to Gausha. He's an Olympian. I take the rhythm of the boxing match, and that's when I take over. He's fighting with the best in the division. He's not a stupid fighter, but he knew who he was facing today." Lara earned $700,000 for the fight and Gausha had a $250,000 purse.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-drops-decisions-terrell-gausha-results--121447|title=Erislandy Lara Drops, Decisions Terrell Gausha in a Snoozer - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/21027024/junior-middleweight-world-titleholder-erislandy-lara-defeats-terrell-gausha|title=Lara keeps belt in lackluster win over Gausha|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-10-15}}</ref> This fight, which was the main event of a triple header, averaged 399,000 viewers and peaked at 476,000 viewers on Showtime.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/showtime-viewership-went-down-during-lara-gausha-main-event--121529|title=Showtime Viewership Went Down During Lara-Gausha Main Event - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-10-18}}</ref>
==== Lara vs. Hurd ==== [[Demetrius Andrade]] vacated his WBA 'Regular' title on October 22, 2017 after making his debut at middleweight. The WBA, in their efforts to reduce the amount of titles in each weight division, promoted Interim titleholder [[Brian Castaño]] (14-0, 10 KOs) to 'Regular' champion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/now?nowId=21-40007487-4|title=WBA promote Castano to Regular champion|last=|first=|date=2017-10-30|website=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-10-30}}</ref> On October 29, the WBA ordered the fight between Lara and Castaño.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.badlefthook.com/2017/10/29/16568872/wba-to-order-erislandy-lara-vs-brian-castano+&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=uk|title=WBA to order Erislandy Lara vs. Brian Castano|work=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-10-30}}</ref> On January 9, 2018 it was confirmed that a deal was being put in place for a unification fight between Lara and [[List of IBF world champions#Junior middleweight|IBF light middleweight]] champion [[Jarrett Hurd]] (21-0, 15 KO) for April 2018 with Showtime televising the bout.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/erislandy-lara-vs-jarrett-hurd-deal-getting-very-close-april--124106|title=Erislandy Lara vs. Jarrett Hurd Deal Getting Very Close For April|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-us}}</ref> On January 25, the fight was confirmed to take place on April 7.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/2018/01/25/news/spectacular-showtime-pbc-unveil-sensational-six-months-featuring-many-world-title-fights|title=Spectacular! - Showtime / PBC unveil sensational six months featuring mass of world title fights|last=RINGSIDE|work=WBN - World Boxing News|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/broner-figueroa-stevenson-jack-lara-hurd-set-showtime--124600|title=Broner-Figueroa, Stevenson-Jack, Lara-Hurd Set For Showtime|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-us}}</ref> It was reported Lara would receive a purse of $1 million and Hurd would receive a $500,000 purse. Lara weighed 153.5 pounds and Hurd came in slightly lighter at 153 pounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingnews24.com/2018/04/purses-lara-1-million-hurd-500k/|title=Purses: Lara $1 million, Hurd $500K » Boxing News|date=2018-04-06|work=Boxing News 24|access-date=2018-04-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
Hurd won a 12 round split decision over Lara in what was a potential fight of a year candidate to become a unified light middleweight champion. With the fight in the balance, Hurd knocked Lara down with a short left hook in round 12 with a minute remaining. Lara was hurt from the knockdown, but was able to get up and still throw some nice shots. Hurd dominated the final round. Two judges scored the fight 114-113 for Hurd and the third judge had the same score for Lara, meaning the knockdown was the deciding factor in the fight. A lot of rounds where close with Lara using effective counter punching and combinations, whereas Hurd used his size to stalk Lara and land power shots.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/jarrett-hurd-vs-erislandy-lara-official-scorecards-photo--126988|title=Jarrett Hurd vs. Erislandy Lara - Official Scorecards - Photo|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-us}}</ref> Lara's right eye began to swell from round 7 and was eventually cut at the start of round 12. Lara started the fight the better boxer of the two, due to Hurd not putting as much pressure on Lara until the later rounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/jarrett-hurd-drops-decisions-erislandy-lara-unify-results--126978|title=Jarrett Hurd Drops, Decisions Erislandy Lara To Unify Titles|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-us}}</ref> With the win, Hurd became seventh unified world title holder in light middleweight history, joining Hall of Famers [[Terry Norris]], [[Félix Trinidad]], [[Oscar De La Hoya]] and [[Winky Wright]], as well as [[Floyd Mayweather Jr.]] and [[Canelo Álvarez]].
Despite the knockdown, Lara thought he had a good enough lead to win the fight. Had Lara not been knocked down, the fight would have finished a majority draw with both boxers keeping their respective belts. In regards to the decision, Lara said, "Besides the last round, I thought I was winning this fight easily. That's not to decide the fight. One punch in a fight doesn't determine the fight. One hundred percent I want the rematch. The problem was the cut on the eye. I couldn't see in the last round." After the fight, Hurd said, "It was a tough one, but I went out there and did exactly what I said I was going to do -- fight all 12 rounds and get the victory. I didn't feel like that [12th-round knockdown for the win]. I feel like I was in control the whole fight, applying the pressure." According to CompuBox statistics, Hurd landed 217 of 824 punches thrown (26%) and Lara landed 176 of his 572 thrown (31%). Hurd outlanded Lara 106-71 in the final four rounds, with 96 being power shots compared to Lara's 58 power punches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/23072088/jarrett-hurd-defeats-erislandy-lara-split-decision-junior-middleweight-unification-bout|title=Hurd's split decision win over Lara unifies titles|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-04-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbssports.com/boxing/news/final-round-drama-lifts-jarrett-hurd-past-erislandy-lara-in-match-of-the-year-candidate/|title=Final-round drama lifts Jarrett Hurd past Erislandy Lara in match of the year candidate|work=CBSSports.com|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en}}</ref> The fight, televised on Showtime, averaged 490,000 viewers and peaked at 521,000 viewers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/hurd-lara-drew-higher-ratings-showtime-joshua-parker--127050|title=Hurd-Lara Drew Higher Ratings for Showtime Than Joshua-Parker|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-us}}</ref>
Although the WBA ordered a direct rematch between Lara and Hurd, the latter rejected the idea stating he wanted to move on to bigger fights to become undisputed light middleweight champion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/jarrett-hurd-vs-erislandy-lara-rematch-ordered--127540|title=Jarrett Hurd vs. Erislandy Lara Rematch Ordered|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-us}}</ref>
=== Later career === In October 2018, at the WBC annual convention in Kiev, it was announced that Jermell Charlo would be allowed to make another voluntary defence and Lara was ordered to fight [[Julian Williams (boxer)|Julian Williams]] (25-1-1, 15 KOs, 1 NC) in a final eliminator. At the time, Williams was already IBF's #1 ranked.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/lara-williams-eliminator-become-charlos-wbc-mandatory--132404|title=Lara-Williams Eliminator to Become Charlo's WBC Mandatory|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-us}}</ref> On October 30, according to [[Brian Castaño]]'s manager Sebastian Contursis, a deal was being worked out to have Castaño fight Lara. A date in January 2019 was being discussed. In order for Castaño to defend his WBA 'Regular' belt against Lara, the WBA granted him a special permit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/brian-castano-vs-erislandy-lara-showdown-eyed-january--133271|title=Brian Castano vs. Erislandy Lara Showdown Eyed For January|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-us}}</ref>

[[File:Paul raiseth Eutychus to life.jpg|thumb|200px|''Paul raiseth Eutychus to life'', from ''Figures de la Bible'', 1728.]] :''Not to be confused with [[Eutychius (disambiguation)|Eutychius]] or the early Christian theologian [[Eutyches]].'' __NOTOC__ '''Eutychus''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|j|uː|t|ᵻ|k|ə|s}} was a young man (or a youth) of [[Alexandria Troas|Troas]] tended to by [[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]]. Eutychus fell asleep due to the long nature of the discourse Paul was giving and fell from a windowsill out of the three-story building.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+20:7-12&version=KJV|title=Bible Gateway passage: Acts 20:7-12 - King James Version|author=|date=|website=Bible Gateway|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> Paul then embraced him, insisting that he was not dead, and they carried him back upstairs alive; those gathered then had a meal and a long talk which lasted until dawn. This is related in the [[New Testament]] book of the [[Acts 20|Acts of the Apostles]] 20:7-12.
Though some (e.g. [[William Barclay (theologian)|William Barclay]], [[F. F. Bruce]]), do not believe that Eutychus died, Wayne Jackson observes the following facts: 1) the author [[St. Luke|Luke]], a physician (Col. 4:14), plainly states that Eutychus was "taken up dead" ({{lang-gr|ἤρθη νεκρός}}, ''erthe nekros''); 2) after Paul embraces Eutychus, he says, "Trouble not yourselves, for his life is in him" ({{lang-gr|ἡ γὰρ ψυχὴ αὐτοῦ ἐν αὐτῷ ἐστιν}}, ''he gar psuche autou en auto estin''), not "still in him" as the [[Weymouth New Testament|Weymouth translation]] erroneously interprets; 3) Eutychus was then "brought alive" by which the others were "not a little comforted," which words would make no sense if Eutychus had not died; and 4) Luke was fully capable of describing someone as only being "supposedly dead" ({{lang-gr|νομισαντες αυτον τεθναναι}}), as he did of Paul in {{bibleverse||Acts|14:19|NKJV}}, but he did not do so here.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christiancourier.com/articles/808-the-case-of-eutychus|title=The Case of Eutychus|author=|date=|website=Christian Courier|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> However, Eutychus' complete recovery from a three-story fall, regardless of the initial result, and Paul's attendance at the scene of the accident, appears to be the impact of the narrative.
The name ''Eutychus'' means "fortunate".

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name=George Rodgers |honorific_suffix= |birth_date={{birth-date|df=y|January 1829}} |death_date={{Death date and age|df=yes|1870|03|9|1829|01}} |birth_place=[[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] |death_place=Glasgow |placeofburial=[[Southern Necropolis]] |image= Victoria Cross Medal without Bar.png |image_size= 125 |caption= |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|United Kingdom}} |serviceyears= |rank=[[private (rank)|Private]] |branch={{army|United Kingdom}} |commands= |unit=[[71st Regiment of Foot]] |battles= {{plainlist| *[[Crimean War]] *[[Indian Mutiny]] *[[Umbeyla Campaign]] }} |awards= [[Victoria Cross]] |laterwork= }} '''George Rodgers''' [[Victoria Cross|VC]] (January 1829 – 9 March 1870) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces.
==Details== Rodgers was about 29 years old, and a [[private (rank)|private]] in the [[71st (Highland) Regiment of Foot|71st Regiment]] (later The [[Highland Light Infantry]]), [[British Army]] during the [[Indian Mutiny]] when the following deed took place on 16 June 1858 at [[Marar]], [[Gwalior]] for which he was awarded the VC: {{quote|For daring conduct at Marar, Gwalior, on the 16th of June, 1858, in attacking by himself a party of seven Rebels, one of whom he killed. This was remarked as a valuable service, the party of Rebels being well armed and strongly posted in the line of advance of a detachment of the 71st Regiment.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=22324|page=4033|date=11 November 1859}}</ref>}}
Rodgers returned to Glasgow and died in a domestic accident. He visited his sister in order to get an alcoholic drink but was refused and told to lie down in her flat. Some time later Rodgers got up and found a bottle of [[sulphuric acid]] and thinking it was alcohol, drank it, causing his death. He was buried in a common grave in Glasgow's [[Southern Necropolis]].<ref>[http://www.glasgow.gov.uk/en/Residents/Parks_Outdoors/HeritageTrails/SouthernNecropolis/southernnecropolisheritagetrail25to28.htm Glasgow Council]</ref>
==The medal== His Victoria Cross is displayed at the Museum of The Royal Highland Fusiliers, [[Glasgow]], Scotland.

{{redirect|Grouch|video game|Grouch (video game)}} {{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} The '''Grouches''' are a race of creatures in ''[[Sesame Street]]''.
==Background== Grouches are an eccentric race of pessimistic, argumentative, and unhygienic furry creatures who prefer to live wherever [[Waste|trash]] can be found: [[Waste container|trash cans]], city dumps, even the occasional landfill (although, some Grouches live in crummy houses, broken cars, and some live in "yucky beautiful houses"). Grouches are a distinct species from the Sesame Street Monsters (including the [[List_of_Muppets#Whatnots|Anything Monsters]]).
Being as grouchy and miserable as they possibly can be is any Grouch's main mission in life. They also feel that they have to make everyone else feel the same way. Even though that makes them happy, however, a Grouch will never admit to being happy no matter what the circumstances.
Grouches like anything dirty or dingy or dusty, anything ragged or rotten or rusty or trashy. They will only buy non-functioning or malfunctioning appliances, they normally keep elephants, worms, pigs, goats, and donkeys as pets, dine on appalling cuisine (ice cream sundaes with pickles and sardines are a popular Grouch dish, as are mashed bananas with beef gravy and ice cubes), sing out-of-tune, play radios at the highest volume, and bathe in mud as they all love not being clean, and they get their fur styled -- or rather, disarrayed -- at "ugly parlors" instead of beauty parlors. Grouches also like to use phrases such as "scram", "get lost", "go away", "beat it", and "buzz off." A Grouch will never miss an opportunity to make a snarky remark.
As seen in the 1985 film ''[[Sesame Street Presents Follow That Bird|Follow That Bird]]'', a handful of human beings have embraced the Grouch way of life, proving themselves to be as hostile, surly, and filthy as any furry Grouch. Two such human Grouches were seen working at the Don't Drop Inn, a small [[googie]]-style Grouch [[diner]] with exaggerated [[greasy spoon]] service (inspired by [[Mel's Drive-In]]) whose patrons included both furry Grouches and disagreeable humans who might or might not themselves have been human Grouches.
Even though [[Oscar the Grouch]] and his girlfriend [[Grundgetta]] are the most well-known Grouches, over the years a very large number of Grouches have been introduced.
Most of the Grouches live in Grouchland USA (inspired by [[Brooklyn]], New York) as seen in the film ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]''. Though the Grouches there had to put up with having their stuff taken by a man named Huxley, Oscar the Grouch later convinced the inhabitants that even though Grouches hate working together, they had to cooperate just this once in order to take a stand against Huxley.
==Known Grouches== * '''[[Oscar the Grouch]]''' (performed by [[Caroll Spinney]] (1969 – 2018); [[Eric Jacobson]] (2015 – present) – A Grouch who lives on [[Sesame Street (fictional location)|Sesame Street]] in a [[Sesame Street (fictional location)#Oscar the Grouch's Trash Can|trash can]], and the most famous Grouch in the world. He was designed by [[Jim Henson]] and his original puppet was built by [[Don Sahlin]]. * '''[[Grundgetta]]''' (performed by [[Brian Meehl|Brian Muehl]] (1980 – 1984), [[Pam Arciero]] (1984 – present)) – Oscar the Grouch's girlfriend/best friend. * '''Bad Humor Man''' (performed by [[Steve Whitmire]]) – The Bad Humor Man is a Grouch [[ice cream]] [[vendor]] who lives in Grouchland as seen in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]''. The Bad Humor Man was different from the Bad Humor Man that appeared in Episode 3085 where he was made from a different Grouch puppet and performed by [[Jerry Nelson]]. He is a parody of the Good Humor Man. * '''Blecka''' (performed by [[Julianne Buescher]]) – A Grouch who appears in Episode 3133 attending Lillian's home care. * '''Bunny''' (performed by [[Stephanie D'Abruzzo]]) – Oscar the Grouch's sister. She appeared in Episode 4237 as a surprise guest on Grouchy Mother's Day. * '''Dan Rather-not''' (performed by [[Joey Mazzarino]]) – A Grouch [[News presenter|newsman]]. He is a parody of [[Dan Rather]]. * '''Donald Grump''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]]) – A Grouch who has more trash than any other Grouch that it spills out of his trash can. He is a parody of [[Donald Trump]]. * '''Don't Drop Inn cook''' (played by [[Paul Bartel]]) - A human Grouch man; his assistant is a green-furred Grouch in a paper hat. * '''Don't Drop Inn waitress''' (played by [[Sandra Bernhard]]) - A human Grouch woman; when a customer complains about their being no fly in their soup, she assures them that "It's comin'!", and when another demands a glass, she offers the choice of "Broken or dirty?!" * '''Dusty''' (performed by [[Eric Jacobson]]) – A white Grouch drummer with an Australian accent that appeared in Episode 3950. * '''Ernest the Grouch''' (performed by [[Jerry Nelson]]) – Oscar the Grouch's brother. He visited Oscar in Episode 2895. * '''Gary Grouch''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]]) – A gray Grouch who was a contestant in "The Alphabet Game" compilation video. His puppet was also seen in background cameos. * '''Grandpa Grouch''' (performed by [[Richard Hunt (puppeteer)|Richard Hunt]]) – Oscar the Grouch's grandfather. * '''Granny Grouch''' (performed by [[Jerry Nelson]]) – Oscar the Grouch's grandmother. She appeared in Episode 131. * '''Grizzy''' (performed by [[Stephanie D'Abruzzo]]) – A young freckled female Grouch child who is shown to be surprisingly sweet and kind-hearted (unlike most Grouches, who are very rude.) She appeared in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]'' and her puppet was built by [[Mark Zeszotek]]. * '''Grouch [[Taxicab|Cab]] Driver''' (performed by [[Kevin Clash]]) – The Grouch Cab Driver is an inhabitant of Grouchland as seen in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]''. * '''Grouch Ice Cream Customer''' (performed by [[David Rudman]]) – A Grouch inhabitant of Grouchland who is seen in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]'' buying an ice cream cone from the Bad Humor Man. The same puppet was also used for Sharon Groan. * '''Grouch [[Prison officer|Jailer]]''' (performed by [[Kevin Clash]]) – A Grouch Jailer that works at Grouchland's Police Department in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]''. When Oscar the Grouch convinces the Grouches to take a stand against Huxley, the Grouch Jailer is ordered by the Grouch Police Officer to release the Sesame Street inhabitants that he was guarding. * '''Grouch [[Mayor]]''' (performed by [[Jerry Nelson]]) – He is the unnamed Mayor of Grouchland as seen in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]'' whose face is in the style of [[Groucho Marx]]. His costume was inspired by the Mayor of [[Munchkins|Munchkinland]] from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''. * '''Grouch [[Police officer|Police Officer]]''' (performed by [[Jerry Nelson]]) – A Grouch that works as a police officer in Grouchland as seen in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]''. He was responsible for arresting the Sesame Street inhabitants that came looking for Elmo after Big Bird broke the Grouchland law of asking a police officer for help. When Oscar the Grouch convinces the Grouches to take a stand against Huxley, the Grouch Police Officer has the Sesame Street inhabitants released. * '''Hairy Hairy More Contrary''' (performed by [[Joey Mazzarino]]) – A Grouch counterpart of [[Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary]] that appeared in Episode 4198. * '''Irvine''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]]) – Oscar the Grouch's baby niece. Irvine appeared in many episodes over the years. In Episode 2630, she got and beat the Grouch Flu. * '''Lothar the Grouch''' (performed by [[Brian Meehl|Brian Muehl]]) – An [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] Grouch from outer space. * '''Luba Merquick''' (performed by [[Kevin Clash]]) – A Grouch from Slime Bottom, Arizona who appears on Oscar the Grouch's reality show "[[Real People#References in other series|Real Grouches]]" (a parody of ''[[Real People]]''). * '''Moe, Moe, and Moe''' – Three Grouches who own a moving company named "Three Grouches named Moe with a Truck." Oscar the Grouch enlisted them in Episode 3851 to help him sell his trash to make room in his trash can. * '''Mr. Grouch''' – Oscar the Grouch's father who appeared in the book "How to Be a Grouch." * '''[[Mrs. Grouch]]''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]] from 1992 to 1993, [[Leslie Carrara-Rudolph]] in 2010) – Oscar the Grouch's mother. * '''Nikola Messla''' (played by [[Jason Jones (actor)|Jason Jones]]) - A human Grouch professor at a [[college]] for Grouches called "Putrid University" who gives the online Grouchology test and appeared in Episode 4260. He is a parody of [[Nikola Tesla]]. * '''Omagrossa''' (performed by [[Fran Brill]]) – A Grouch who appeared in Episode 4104 where she auditioned to be Donald Grump's helper. Her name is a take on [[Omarosa Manigault|Omarosa Manigault-Stallworth]], the infamous contestant who appeared on the reality series ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]''. * '''Osvaldo, el Gruñón''' (performed by [[Richard Hunt (puppeteer)|Richard Hunt]] and voiced by [[Norberto Kerner]] in Episode 1316, [[Gabriel Velez]] in the 1980s, [[Peter Linz]] in the 1990s) – Oscar the Grouch's [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] counterpart. * '''Othmar the Grouch''' (performed by [[Brian Meehl|Brian Muehl]]) – An [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] Grouch from the seventh moon of the planet Zurkon who visits Earth in Episode 1755. He was built by [[Cheryl Blaylock]]. * '''Otto the Grouch''' – Oscar the Grouch's brother who appears in the 1975 book "How to Be a Grouch" * '''Phooey Louie''' (performed by [[Joey Mazzarino]]) – A Grouch guitarist that appeared in Episode 3950. * '''Prunella''' (performed by [[Louise Gold]]) – A gray British Grouch who appeared in Episode 3119 stopping by Sesame Street during her tour across the United States of America. * '''Rhubarb the Grouch''' (voiced by [[Rickey Boyd]]) – A Grouch [[Ghost]] who appears in ''[[A Sesame Street Christmas Carol]]'' as the "Grouch of Christmas Past." His CGI form was done by [[Magnetic Dreams]]. * '''Romeo Scuggs''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]]) – A Grouch from Gila Monster, [[New Mexico]] who appears on Oscar the Grouch's reality show "Real Grouches" (a parody of ''[[Real People]]''). *'''Ronald Grump''' - A landlord who built Grump Tower. Another parody of [[Donald Trump]]. * '''Roscoe''' – Oscar the Grouch's cousin who lives in [[Poughkeepsie, New York]]. * '''Sally Messy Yuckayael''' (performed by [[Louise Gold]]) – A Grouch who hosts her own talk show. She is a parody of [[Sally Jessy Raphael]]. Her puppet was also used for different AM Monsters. * '''Sharon Groan''' (performed by [[Steve Whitmire]]) – Sharon Groan appears in ''[[The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland]]'' as the star of the movie ''Basically It Stinks'' and is an unpopular Grouchland celebrity. She is a parody of [[Sharon Stone]] and the puppet was also used for a Grouch Ice Cream Customer in the same movie. Her puppet later appeared in Episode 4203 as a spectator of the Squimadega Car Race. * '''Slam''' (performed by [[Stephanie D'Abruzzo]]) – A Grouch pianist who appears in Episode 3950. * '''Snow Grouch''' (performed by [[Fran Brill]]) – A Grouch parody of [[Snow White]] that appeared in the story "Snow Grouch and the Seven Dwarfs" as seen in Episode 2630. * '''Spill O'Reilly''' (performed by [[Joey Mazzarino]]) – A Grouch [[News presenter|newscaster]] for the Grouch News Network. He is a parody of [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]]. * '''Swampy''' (performed by [[Joey Mazzarino]]) – A Grouch who appeared in Episode 4104 where she auditioned to be Donald Grump's helper. He is a parody of [[Kwame Jackson]] who appeared on the reality series ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]''. * '''Walter Cranky''' (performed by [[Martin P. Robinson]]) – A Grouch [[News presenter|newsman]]. He is a parody of [[Walter Cronkite]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox military person |name = Hector Macdonald Laws (Hec) Waller |image = Hector Waller AWM 005002-13 (crop).jpg |caption = Waller on the bridge of HMAS ''Stuart'' in 1940 |alt=Informal head-and-shoulders portrait of man in dark coat and sweater, smoking a pipe |birth_date = 4 April 1900 |death_date = {{Death date and age|1942|03|01|1900|04|04|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Benalla, Victoria|Benalla]], Victoria |death_place = [[Missing in action]] at [[Sunda Strait]] |nickname = "Hard Over Hec" |allegiance = Australia |branch = [[Royal Australian Navy]] |serviceyears = 1913–42 |rank = [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] |unit = |commands = [[HMS Brazen (H80)|HMS ''Brazen'']] (1937–39)

[[Spanish Civil War]]
World War II * [[Mediterranean, Middle East and African theatres of World War II|Mediterranean theatre]] * [[Battle of Calabria]] * [[Operation Lustre]] * [[Battle of Cape Matapan]] * [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] * [[Battle of the Java Sea]] * [[Battle of Sunda Strait]] |awards = [[Distinguished Service Order]] & [[Medal bar|Bar]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (3) |relations = }} '''Hector Macdonald Laws (Hec) Waller''', [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] and [[Medal bar|Bar]] (4 April 1900 – 1 March 1942) was a senior officer in the [[Royal Australian Navy]] (RAN). His career spanned almost thirty years, including service in both world wars. At the helm of [[HMAS Stuart (D00)|HMAS ''Stuart'']] in the [[Mediterranean, Middle East and African theatres of World War II|Mediterranean]] from 1939 to 1941, he won recognition as a skilful ship's captain and [[flotilla]] commander. He then transferred to the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]] as captain of the light cruiser [[HMAS Perth (D29)|HMAS ''Perth'']], and went down with his ship against heavy odds during the [[Battle of Sunda Strait]] in early 1942. Born in [[Benalla]], Victoria, Waller entered the [[HMAS Creswell|Royal Australian Naval College]] at the age of thirteen. After graduating, he served with the [[Royal Navy]] in the closing stages of World War I. Between the wars, he specialised in communications and was posted as signals officer to several British and Australian warships. He gained his first seagoing command in 1937, as captain of the destroyer [[HMS Brazen (H80)|HMS ''Brazen'']]. In September 1939, he took charge of HMAS ''Stuart'' and four other obsolete destroyers that together became known as the "[[Scrap Iron Flotilla]]". In 1940, these were augmented by other ships to form the 10th Destroyer Flotilla, supporting Allied troops in [[North African Campaign|North Africa]]. Waller was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] and [[Medal bar|Bar]], and twice [[mentioned in despatches]], for his achievements in the Mediterranean. He assumed command of HMAS ''Perth'' in October 1941, taking part in the [[Battle of the Java Sea]] shortly before his final action in Sunda Strait. He received a third mention in despatches posthumously, and in 2011 came under formal consideration for the award of the [[Victoria Cross]] for his performance as ''Perth'''s captain. The submarine [[HMAS Waller (SSG 75)|HMAS ''Waller'']] is named in his honour. ==Early life and World War I== Born on 4 April 1900 in [[Benalla, Victoria|Benalla]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Hector MacDonald Laws Waller was the son of William Frederick Waller, a grocer, and his wife Helen Waller (née Duncan).{{cite web|author=Goldrick, J. V. P.|authorlink=James Goldrick|year=2002| url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A160565b.htm|title=Waller, Hector Macdonald (Hec) (1900–1942) |work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|publisher=[[Australian National University]]|accessdate=12 December 2011}}Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", p. 1. Hec Waller was named in honour of General [[Hector MacDonald]], hero of the [[Boer War]], and a forebear called Laws who was an [[admiral]] and a contemporary of [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Nelson]].McKie (1953), ''Proud Echo'', p. 25. The youngest of ten children, of whom eight survived infancy, he attended Benalla Higher Elementary School. Waller entered the [[HMAS Creswell|Royal Australian Naval College]] (RANC) as a cadet midshipman on 31 December 1913, aged thirteen.{{cite web|title=Waller immortalised|date=22 May 2009|author=Dowling, Matt|work=ABC Goulburn Murray |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2009/05/22/2577921.htm|accessdate=12 December 2011}} He gained recognition as a [[rugby union|rugby]] player and became cadet captain.Eldridge (1949), ''A History of the Royal Australian Naval College'', p. 438. In 1917, his final year at the college, he was raised to chief cadet captain and won the King's Medal, awarded for "gentlemanly bearing, character, good influence among his fellows and officer-like qualities".Eldridge (1949), ''A History of the Royal Australian Naval College'', pp. 79–80. Promoted to [[midshipman]] on 1 January 1918, he was posted to Britain where, in April, he was appointed to serve in the [[Royal Navy]]'s (RN) [[Grand Fleet]] with the [[dreadnought]] [[HMS Agincourt (1913)|HMS ''Agincourt'']].Dennis et al. (2008), ''The Oxford Companion to Australian Military History'', p. 563. The ship did not see combat while he was on board.Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 2–3. ==Between the wars== In February 1919, Waller was assigned to the light cruiser [[HMAS Melbourne (1912)|HMAS ''Melbourne'']], and two months later returned to Australia. He transferred to the light cruiser [[HMAS Sydney (1912)|HMAS ''Sydney]] as an acting [[sub-lieutenant]] in September; his rank was made substantive the following month.{{cite journal |author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 October 1919)| location=Melbourne|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-October-1919.pdf|page=33|accessdate=12 December 2011}}{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 October 1920)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-October-1920.pdf|page=22|accessdate=12 December 2011}} In April 1920 he was again posted aboard ''Melbourne''.{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 January 1921)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-January-1921.pdf|page=30|accessdate=12 December 2011}} Promoted to [[lieutenant (navy)|lieutenant]] in March 1921, he underwent further training in Britain before returning to join the staff of the RANC. Waller married Nancy Bowes, a [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]]'s daughter, on 7 April 1923 in the [[Sydney]] suburb of [[Lewisham, New South Wales|Lewisham]]; the couple had two sons, Michael and John. In April 1924, he was posted to the light cruiser [[HMAS Adelaide (1918)|HMAS ''Adelaide'']]. Later that year, he began training as a signals officer in England; his classmates included [[Louis Mountbatten|Lord Louis Mountbatten]]. Waller finished at the top of the advanced course and, in May 1926, took charge of the Signals and Wireless-Telegraphy School at [[HMAS Cerberus (naval base)|Flinders Naval Depot]] in [[Western Port|Westernport]], Victoria. From 1928 to 1930, he served with the RN as a signals officer aboard the destroyer [[HMS Broke (1914)|HMS ''Broke'']]. He was promoted to [[lieutenant commander]] in March 1929. [[File:HMS Brazen AWM 302321.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|HMS ''Brazen'' was Waller's first command at sea.|alt=Three-quarter front view of destroyer with twin funnels and two forward gun turrets, at sea]] By this stage of his career, Waller had acquired a strong reputation for his communications work. In July 1930, he was posted aboard the [[Royal Australian Navy]]'s (RAN) flagship, the heavy cruiser [[HMAS Australia (D84)|HMAS ''Australia'']], as squadron signals officer. He continued to perform this role upon transferring to ''Australia''{{'}}s sister ship, [[HMAS Canberra (D33)|HMAS ''Canberra'']], in May 1931.{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 October 1931)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-October-1931.pdf|page=35|accessdate=12 December 2011}} In early 1932, he was assigned to the Navy Office in [[Melbourne]], returning to ''Canberra'' as squadron signals officer in August 1933.{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 April 1932)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-April-1932.pdf|page=14|accessdate=12 December 2011}}{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (1 October 1933)| location=Melbourne|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-October-1933.pdf|page=37|accessdate=12 December 2011}} He was promoted to [[commander]] in June 1934 and the following month became executive officer of the RANC. Departing the college in July 1936, he returned to England and spent six months working in the British Naval Intelligence Division. A stint as executive officer of the repair ship HMS ''Resource'' followed.Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 4–5. In November 1937, Waller was given his first command at sea, the RN destroyer [[HMS Brazen (H80)|HMS ''Brazen'']].{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (January 1938)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-January-1938.pdf|page=52|accessdate=12 December 2011}} His ship handling was criticised early on, but was soon reported by his superiors as having "improved greatly". Stationed in the Mediterranean, ''Brazen'' monitored progress of the [[Spanish Civil War]], a duty that included protecting [[Merchant Navy (United Kingdom)|British merchant vessels]] and rescuing the crews of sinking ships.Stevens (2001), ''The Royal Australian Navy: A History'', p. 97. By June 1939, Waller had returned to Australia to become Director of Signals and Communications at the Navy Office.{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (July 1939)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-July-1939.pdf|pages=7, 18, 45|accessdate=28 December 2011}} ==World War II== ===HMAS ''Stuart'' in the Mediterranean=== [[File:HMAS Stuart (AWM P01593-002).jpg|right|thumb|upright=1.2|HMAS ''Stuart'', pictured in 1938, came under Waller's command when World War II began.|alt=Three-quarter front view of destroyer with twin funnels and two forward gun turrets, at sea]] At the [[Military history of Australia in World War II|outbreak of World War II]], Waller was appointed captain of [[HMAS Stuart (D-00/100)|HMAS ''Stuart'']], taking charge of a group of four other obsolete ex-RN destroyers—[[HMAS Vampire (D68)|HMA Ships ''Vampire'']], [[HMAS Vendetta (D69)|''Vendetta'']], [[HMAS Voyager (D31)|''Voyager'']], and [[HMAS Waterhen (D22)|''Waterhen'']]—that the Germans later nicknamed the "[[Scrap Iron Flotilla]]".Frame (2004), ''No Pleasure Cruise'', p. 153. The ships were en route to [[Singapore]] for training when the British and Australian governments agreed that they should be assigned to the [[Mediterranean, Middle East and African theatres of World War II|Mediterranean]] as the 19th Destroyer Division, under Waller's control.Stevens (1996), ''The Royal Australian Navy in World War II'', p. 67. Arriving at [[Malta]] in late December, Waller made a positive initial impression on senior RN commanders; this was soon borne out by his actions during the salvage of the ''Trocas'', a disabled tanker. In May 1940, he was appointed to command the 10th Destroyer Flotilla, which included the vessels of the "Scrap Iron Flotilla" plus four modern British destroyers, and a month later was promoted to [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]]. Following Italy's entry into the war on 10 June 1940, Waller was involved in the search for minefields off the North African coast. A keen shooter, he personally blew up floating mines using a rifle and armour-piercing bullets. On 21 June, ''Stuart'' shelled the Italian-held town of [[Bardia]].Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 9–10. The next month, his 10th Destroyer Flotilla participated in the [[Battle of Calabria]]. Waller's ships carried out bombardments on [[Fort Capuzzo]] on 17 August and an Italian seaplane base in the [[Gulf of Bomba]] one week later.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20141213095728/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070340--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 206–207]. In September, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] (DSO) for "courage, enterprise, and devotion to duty on recent engagements"—in particular, his pinpointing of enemy minefields.{{London Gazette|issue=34943|date=10 September 1940|page=5469|supp=y}} The same month, he transferred to HMAS ''Vampire'' while ''Stuart'' went in for refit.Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 10–11. As the [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] armies began to [[Operation Compass|counterattack Italian forces]] in December 1940, the Commander-in-Chief of the [[Mediterranean Fleet (United Kingdom)|Mediterranean Fleet]], Admiral [[Andrew Cunningham, 1st Viscount Cunningham of Hyndhope|Sir Andrew Cunningham]], gave Waller command of the newly formed Inshore Squadron, comprising destroyers, minesweepers, and auxiliaries. In his role as Cunningham's Senior Officer Afloat, Waller took charge of naval support for the [[Battle of Bardia|attack on Bardia]], which fell to the Allies on 5 January 1941.Stevens (1996), ''The Royal Australian Navy in World War II'', pp. 70–75.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20141213110436/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070342--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 292]. Shortly afterwards, he handed over command of the Inshore Squadron and transferred back aboard ''Stuart''. {{Quote box |width=35% |align=left |quote=The cooks & stewards nicknamed Waller 'Hard Over Hec' as most of his wheel orders, in action, were 'Hard a Stbd or Hard a Port'. Waller would lay back in his chair, with pipe in mouth, on the bridge and actually wait for the dive-bombers to release their bombs before ordering the wheel hard over one way or the other! |source=—Crewman quoted by historian [[Tom Lewis (author)|Tom Lewis]]}} ''Stuart'' and other ships of Waller's 10th Destroyer Flotilla supported the [[Battle of Tobruk (1941)|assaults on Tobruk]] in January 1941 and [[Benghazi#World War II|Benghazi]] the following month.Frame (2004), ''No Pleasure Cruise'', p. 160. In March, ''Stuart'' escorted Allied troop transports to Greece as part of [[Operation Lustre]], narrowly avoiding falling victim to [[Axis powers|Axis]] dive-bomber attacks.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20141213102938/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070343--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 304–306]. During the [[Battle of Cape Matapan]] at the end of the month, Waller's ships were credited with sinking two Italian destroyers. From May to July, the 10th Destroyer Flotilla made 139 ferry runs during the [[Siege of Tobruk]], carrying supplies to the town's garrison and evacuating the wounded.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20141213093731/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070346--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 390–395]. Waller was [[mentioned in despatches]] twice during 1941: in July for his army cooperation role with the Inshore Squadron off the Libyan coast, and in November for his service during the Greek campaign.{{London Gazette|issue=35231|date=25 July 1941|page=4370|supp=y}}{{London Gazette|issue=35342|date=7 November 1941|page=6495|supp=y}} In January 1942, he was awarded a [[Medal bar|Bar]] to his DSO for "bravery and enterprise in the Battle of Cape Matapan".{{London Gazette|issue=35443|date=30 January 1942|page=553|supp=y}} Waller earned the personal admiration of Admiral Cunningham, who described him as "one of the finest types of Australian naval officers ... greatly loved and admired by everyone".Stevens (2001), ''The Royal Australian Navy: A History'', p. 112. On the occasion of a visit to [[Alexandria]] by Australian Prime Minister [[Robert Menzies]], Cunningham escorted him to ''Stuart'' and declared: "And now you are going to meet one of the greatest captains who ever sailed the seas—his name is Waller".{{cite web|url=http://www.navyhistory.org.au/sons-of-the-sea/|title= Sons of the Sea – 1947 RAN College Entry|publisher= [[Naval Historical Society of Australia]]|accessdate=12 December 2014}} According to author Ray Parkin, who began writing while a prisoner of war, "Andrew Cunningham and Hector Waller were cast in the same mould: men would follow them, suffer, and be glad about it. These were both men made by Fate for those ever-recurring [[Saint Crispin's Day]]s of human affairs".Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 13, 25.{{cite web|author=Stanley, Peter|authorlink=Peter Stanley|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/atwar/remembering1942/perth/transcript.asp|title=The loss of HMAS ''Perth'', 1 March 1942| work=Remembering 1942|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|date=1 March 2002|accessdate=12 December 2014}} ===HMAS ''Perth'' and the Battle of Sunda Strait=== [[File:HMAS Perth (AWM 301166).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|HMAS ''Perth'' was Waller's final command.|alt=Three-quarter overhead view of cruiser with twin funnels and four gun turrets, at sea]] Departing the Mediterranean, Waller returned to Australia in August 1941 for service in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]].Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20141213093731/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070346--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', p. 391]. On 24 October, he took command of the light cruiser [[HMAS Perth (D29)|HMAS ''Perth'']], berthed in Sydney.Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", p. 16. ''Perth'' had also lately returned from action in the Mediterranean, where she had participated in the Greek, [[Battle of Crete|Cretan]], and [[Syria–Lebanon Campaign|Syrian campaign]]s, and been damaged on two occasions by German bombers.Frame (2004), ''No Pleasure Cruise'', pp. 160–164. Waller was reportedly "tired" and "quite a sick man" at this time, but nonetheless prepared ''Perth'' for action quickly.{{cite web|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=1 August 2011|url=http://www.abc.net.au/austory/content/2011/s3282526.htm|title=A Measure of Courage|work=Australian Story|accessdate=12 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106130804/http://www.abc.net.au/austory/content/2011/s3282526.htm|archive-date=6 January 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In January 1942, the ship was assigned to [[American-British-Dutch-Australian Command]] (ABDA) to help defend the [[Dutch East Indies]]. She set sail for the ABDA Area on 15 February, the day that Singapore surrendered.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20131220064801/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070350--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 578–580]. The ABDA Striking Force that ''Perth'' had joined was crushed by an overwhelming [[Imperial Japanese Navy|Japanese force]] at the [[Battle of the Java Sea]] on 27 February. Low on ammunition, Waller made the decision to withdraw, accompanied by the cruiser [[USS Houston (CA-30)|USS ''Houston'']] under the command of Captain [[Albert H. Rooks]]. Waller's action contravened the orders of his Dutch superior, Admiral [[Conrad Emil Lambert Helfrich|Conrad Helfrich]], to "continue action whatever the cost, and till the bitter end", but the Australian was convinced that further engagement would mean pointless sacrifice.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20131220064801/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070350--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 615–616]. On the following night, 28 February, ''Perth'' and ''Houston'' were attempting to break through the [[Sunda Strait]] to Australia when they encountered a Japanese invasion fleet escorted by four [[cruiser]]s and twelve [[destroyer]]s.Lewis (2004), "The Navy's Finest Fighting Leader", pp. 18–21.Stevens (2001), ''The Royal Australian Navy: A History'', p. 129. As senior officer, Waller was in the lead with ''Perth'', and gave the order to fire upon making contact with the enemy ships just after 11:00 pm.Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20131220064801/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070350--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 619–620]. In the [[Battle of Sunda Strait|ensuing battle]], the Allied cruisers sank four Japanese transports and a minesweeper before they themselves were sunk, shortly after midnight on 1 March 1942. Having fought to the last of its ammunition, ''Perth'' was struck by two torpedoes, losing over 350 of its complement of 680 as it keeled over.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/exhibitions/fiftyaustralians/48.asp|work= Fifty Australians|title=Fighting Hec Waller|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate=12 December 2014}} According to witnesses, Waller was last seen standing on the bridge after he had given the order to abandon ship, "looking down at the silent turrets".Gill (1957), [https://web.archive.org/web/20131220064801/http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070350--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Navy, 1939–1942'', pp. 620–622]. He was officially listed as missing, presumed killed, and was survived by his wife and sons. Admiral Cunningham described Waller's loss as "a heavy deprivation for the young Navy of Australia", and Rear Admiral [[James Goldrick]] subsequently called him "the outstanding officer of his generation". ==Legacy== [[File:HMAS Waller (SSG 75).jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|HMAS ''Waller'' in 2008|alt=Side view of submarine with sailors on deck, at sea in front of a hilly coast]] On 15 March 1946, Waller was awarded a posthumous mention in despatches for "gallantry and resolution" aboard HMAS ''Perth''.{{London Gazette|issue=37505|date=15 March 1946|page=1440|supp=y}} His younger son John followed him into the Navy, entering the RANC in 1947.{{cite journal|author=Commonwealth of Australia (Navy Office)| title=The Navy List (April 1947)| location=Melbourne| url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-April-1947.pdf|page=145|accessdate=12 December 2011}} Graduating as chief cadet captain, John Waller became a weapons electrical engineer and attained the rank of commander in 1967, before transferring to the Emergency Reserve as a senior Navy research scientist.{{cite journal|author=Royal Australian Navy| title=The Navy List (September 1967)| location=Carnegie, Victoria|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/Navy_List-September-1967.pdf|pages=88, 206|accessdate=12 December 2011}} Hec Waller's name appears on the Roll of Honour located at Panel 6 in the Commemorative Area at the [[Australian War Memorial]], Canberra, and on the [[Plymouth Naval Memorial]] in [[Devon]], England.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/roll_of_honour/person.asp?p=524621 |work=Roll of Honour|title=Hector Macdonald Laws Waller|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=12 December 2014}} He is also commemorated by Waller Crescent and Waller Place in the Canberra suburb of [[Campbell, Australian Capital Territory|Campbell]].{{cite web|url=http://www.planning.act.gov.au/tools_resources/place_search/place_search3?sq_content_src=%2BdXJsPWh0dHAlM0ElMkYlMkYyMDMuOS4yNDkuMyUyRlBsYWNlTmFtZXMlMkZQbGFjZURldGFpbHMuYXNweCUzRm9iamVjdElEJTNEMTAzNjgmYWxsPTE%3D|title=Waller web|url=http://www.benalla.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=683|title=Costume and Pioneer Museum|publisher=[[Rural City of Benalla|Benalla Rural City]]|accessdate=12 December
