Recruit School at [[HMAS Cerberus (naval base)|HMAS ''Cerberus'']], Victoria, was named in his honour until his name transferred to a division at RAN College in 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.navy.gov.au/news/renaming-divisions-ran-college-and-ran-recruit-school|title=Renaming of Divisions at RAN College and RAN Recruit School|publisher=[[Royal Australian Navy]]|date=1 March 2013|accessdate=12 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216161048/https://www.navy.gov.au/news/renaming-divisions-ran-college-and-ran-recruit-school|archivedate=16 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} [[HMAS Waller (SSG 75)|HMAS ''Waller'']], the third of the RAN's [[Collins class submarine|''Collins''-class submarines]] to enter service, was commissioned on 10 July 1999. The attendees included John Waller, Michael Waller's wife, and surviving crewmen of HMAS ''Perth''.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/hmas-waller|title= HMAS Waller|publisher= Royal Australian Navy|accessdate=12 December 2014}} On 13 March 2010, a memorial to Waller was unveiled in his home town of Benalla.{{cite web|author=[[Russ Crane|Chief of Navy]]|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/Memorial_to_CAPT_Hector_Waller_unveiled|title=Memorial to Capt Hector Waller unveiled|date=14 March 2010|publisher=Royal Australian Navy|accessdate=12 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405014634/http://www.navy.gov.au/Memorial_to_CAPT_Hector_Waller_unveiled|archivedate=5 April 2012}} In April 2011, he was one of thirteen servicemen—eleven sailors and two soldiers, including [[Teddy Sheean]], [[Robert William Rankin|Robert Rankin]], and [[John Simpson Kirkpatrick]]—named by the Australian government for consideration as possible recipients of the [[Victoria Cross]] for extreme valour in combat, under a review by the Defence Honours and Awards Appeals Tribunal; no RAN member had ever been awarded the decoration.{{cite journal|title=Man with the donkey may at last be recognised|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|location=Sydney|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|author=[[Mike Carlton|Carlton, Mike]]; Welch, Dylan|date=16 April 2011|accessdate=12 December 2011|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/man-with-the-donkey-may-at-last-be-recognised-20110415-1dhw9.html}} Concluding its investigations in February 2013, the tribunal recommended that no further award be made to any of the thirteen servicemen, but that the name ''Waller'' (among others) should continue to be used for RAN ships after the current bearer was decommissioned.{{cite web|url=http://defence-honours-tribunal.gov.au/inquiries/completed-inquiries/valour/|title= Valour|publisher=Defence Honours and Awards Appeals Tribunal|accessdate=12 '''Helen Black''' (1924 - June 8, 2018)<ref name=":2">[https://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/news/2018/06/13/helen-black-conservationist-who-founded.html Helen Black, conservationist who founded Cincinnati Nature Center, dies at 94]</ref> was an American naturalist and [[Conservation movement|conservationist]] from the Greater [[Cincinnati]] area.
== Biography == Helen Black was born in 1924 and grew up in [[Indian Hill, Ohio|Indian Hill]] area of Cincinnati. After graduating from [[Vassar College]] with a degree in English in 1945, her and her husband settled in Indian Hill and committed herself to conservation, having been inspired by an elementary teacher, Louis Brand, at the Lotspeich School and [[Emma Lucy Braun|Dr. Emma Lucy Braun]], a prominent botanist, ecologist and expert on the forests of the eastern United States.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2018/06/12/conservationist-helen-black-founder-nature-center-dead-94/692549002/|title=Helen Black, conservationist who founded Nature Center, saved Union Terminal, dead at 94|work=Cincinnati.com|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}</ref>
Black was one of the founders of the [[Cincinnati Nature Center]] (CNC), the nation's largest member-supported nature center, in 1965 and Little Miami Inc.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 22 Sep 2012, Page S11 - at Newspapers.com|url = http://cincinnati.newspapers.com/image/104153944/?terms=helen%252Bblack|website = Newspapers.com|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = 22 Sep 2012, Page S11 - at Newspapers.com|url = http://cincinnati.newspapers.com/image/104153944/?terms=helen%252Bblack|website = Newspapers.com|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref> She served as vice president of the CNC from 1967 to 1977, later becoming a teaching volunteer, land steward, and active honor trustee and lands committee member. Black was president of the Ohio chapter of [[The Nature Conservancy]] from 1976 to 1978 and board member of the Ohio Environmental Council.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = ODJFS Online {{!}} SEARCH the Ohio Women's Hall of Fame|url = http://www.odjfs.state.oh.us/women/halloffame/bio.asp?ID=23|website = www.odjfs.state.oh.us|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref>
Black was instrumental in the merger that created the [[Cincinnati Museum Center at Union Terminal|Cincinnati Museum Center]] at Union Terminal in 1983. For 20 years, she was on the board of the Cincinnati Museum of Natural History at Gilbert Avenue advocating the merger between the museum and the Cincinnati Historical Society at Union Terminal. In 1995, she joined the board of directors, serving until 2004, when she was named a lifetime emeritus trustee.<ref name=":2" />
She also worked with other regional conservation groups including: [[Edge of Appalachia Preserve]], Greenacres, Indian Hill Garden Club, Redbird Hollow Association, Cincinnati Wildflower Preservation Society, StriveTogether, [[Southwest Ohio Regional Transit Authority]], and Shelterhouse.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 27 Sep 2012, Page A4 - at Newspapers.com|url = http://cincinnati.newspapers.com/image/104156232/?terms=helen%252Bblack|website = Newspapers.com|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
== Awards and Legacy == In 1972, the [[Garden Club of America]] awarded Black the Medal of Merit for Conservation. In 1973, she was awarded the Oak Leaf Award from The Nature Conservancy as well as the Ohio Department of Natural Resources Conservation Award. She was inducted into the [[Ohio Women's Hall of Fame]] in 1978.<ref name=":1" /> In 1981, the Garden Club of America presented her with the Margaret Douglas medal for outstanding service to conservation education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.springgrove.org/obituary.aspx?id=3806|title=Helen C. Black|website=Spring Grove|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> She was nominated along with her husband, Robert L. Black Jr., in 1997 for the Jacob E. Davis Volunteer Leadership Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cincinnati.newspapers.com/image/102439871/?terms=helen%252Bc.%252Bblack|title=7 Oct 1997, Page 43 - at Newspapers.com|website=Newspapers.com|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref> In 2012, the CNC honored her for her work in conservation in the Greater Cincinnati region at their first Awards dinner, where she received the Wood Thrush Award and the creation of the Helen C. Black Conservation Fund, which raises funds to be used for land acquisition and purchasing of conservation easements that curb development in wild areas.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> In 2017, she won the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Ohio Environmental Council.<ref name=":2" />

{{Spanish name 2|Márquez|Beltrán}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Hernán Márquez | image = | caption = | realname = Hernán Márquez Beltrán | nickname = [[Mike Tyson|Tyson]] | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Flyweight]] *[[Super flyweight]] }} | height = 5 ft 3 in | reach = 60 in | nationality = Mexican | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|9|4}} | birth_place = [[Empalme, Sonora]], Mexico | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 52 | wins = 42 | KO = 29 | losses = 8 | draws = 2 }} '''Hernán Márquez Beltrán''' (born September 4, 1988), commonly known by his nickname "'''[[Mike Tyson|Tyson]]'''" '''Márquez''', is a Mexican [[professional boxer]]. He held the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[flyweight]] title from 2011 to 2012, and has challenged once for the WBA [[interim championship|interim]] [[super flyweight]] title in 2010. Márquez is known for his trilogy of fights against [[Luis Concepción]], whom he defeated twice in 2011 and lost to in 2015. ==Professional career== {{Update|section|date=April 2017}} Nicknamed "[[Mike Tyson|Tyson]]" due to his aggressive style, Márquez is a hard-hitting southpaw. Márquez began his professional career on October 21, 2005, with a unanimous decision win over Noe Acosta. On July 25, 2009, he also won the WBC USNBC title with a unanimous decision win against Juan Escuer. Márquez won his following two fights before losing to [[Richie Mepranum]] by a 10-round unanimous decision. In his next fight, he moved up to the super flyweight division in order to challenge [[Nonito Donaire]] for the interim WBA super flyweight title. He lost the bout by 8th round knock out. === WBA flyweight champion === After scoring two consecutive wins, he returned to the Flyweight division and faced WBA world champion [[Luis Concepción]]. Márquez defeated Concepción by 11th round technical knock out to claim the title and become world champion at the age of 22. In an action filled bout, Márquez rose from a first round knock down to drop the champion later in that same round. He also knocked Concepción down in the third and tenth round before stopping him in the eleventh.http://www.boxingscene.com/hernan-marquez-stops-luis-concepcion-fight-year--37724 In his first defense, he defeated [[Edrin Dapudong]] by third-round knockout. In his second WBA World Flyweight Title defense he fought Luis Concepcion for the second time in 2011. He stopped Concepcion in round 1 after scoring three knockdowns. Márquez participated in an [[International Boxing Federation]] title eliminator on June 14, 2014, but was dominated and knocked out in eleven rounds by [[McJoe Arroyo]]. He was knocked down by the Puerto Rican boxer in the first, fourth, eighth and last rounds. ==Professional boxing record== {{BoxingRecordSummary |draws=2 |nc= |ko-wins=29 |ko-losses=5 |dec-wins=13 {{Infobox comics character | character_name = Human Flame | image = Humanflame.PNG | converted = y | caption = The Human Flame from ''Justice League of America'' (vol. 2) #21 (July 2008)
Artist [[Carlos Pacheco]] | publisher = [[DC Comics]] | debut = ''[[Detective Comics]]'' #274
(December 1959) | creators = Jack Miller (writer)
Joe Certa (art) | alter_ego = | full_name = Michael Miller | species = | homeworld = | alliances = [[Secret Society of Super Villains|The Society]] | partners = | aliases = | supports= | powers = Formerly:
Use of a special [[flamethrower|flamethrowing]] suit
Cybernetic enhancements
Implanted miniaturized flamethrowers in hands, mouth, forehead and belly
Currently:
Molten, radioactive body
Ability to increase his mass and density
Ability to create and command flames | cat = super | subcat = DC Comics | villain = y | sortkey = Human Flame }} The '''Human Flame''' is a [[comic book]] [[Character (arts)|character]], a [[supervillain]] in [[DC Comics]]' main [[Shared universe|shared]] [[DC Universe|universe]]. He is mostly known as enemy of [[Martian Manhunter]] ==Publication history== He first appeared in ''[[Detective Comics]]'' #274 (December 1959), and was created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa. The character was not used again for 48 years, before reappearing to play an important role in ''[[Final Crisis]]''. The writer, [[Grant Morrison]], explained why he picked such an obscure character: {{cquote|With The Human Flame, I wanted a Martian Manhunter villain, and I couldn't find a really good one. Then, looking through the old ''[[Showcase Presents]]'' books, I discovered this stupid guy called Mike, who declared himself to be The Human Flame. And he wore a homemade costume with six nipples that shot flames. So I just thought this is a great way to start this book because the idea is that Libra gives all the villains a very simple choice, he says, 'Follow me and I'll give you your heart's desire.' And that's it. And some of the villains naturally say, 'Prove it.' So the Human Flame is one of the first to fall in with Libra and he says, 'If you can get revenge on my old enemy, who has had me stuck in jail for the last five years, I'll follow you anywhere.' I needed a small-scale dumb guy, who could make very big waves and open the book with a shock moment and The Human Flame fit the bill.[http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=16005 ALL STAR GRANT MORRISON I: Final Crisis], [[Comic Book Resources]], April 15, 2008}} Human Flame is the featured character in the six-issue [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] ''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'', written by [[Lilah Sturges]], with art by [[Freddie Williams II|Freddie Williams]].[http://www.newsarama.com/comics/020910-Behind-Sturges2.html Behind the Page - Matthew Sturges, 2], [[Newsarama]], February 10, 2009[http://www.newsarama.com/comics/020911-Sattler-Aftermath.html Ian Sattler on the Final Crisis: Aftermath Titles], [[Newsarama]], February 11, 2009[http://www.newsarama.com/comics/020916-Sturges-Run.html The Most Powerful? Matt Sturges on The Human Flame and Run!], [[Newsarama]], February 16, 2009 ==Fictional character biography== '''Michael Miller''', the Human Flame, was a minor villain who, early in his career, was captured by the [[Martian Manhunter]] and incarcerated, He was the first actual supervillain the Manhunter faced.''[[Detective Comics]]'' (vol. 1) #274 (December 1959) After this one off appearance, he was not seen in publication for nearly fifty years. In 2008's ''[[Justice League|Justice League of America]]'' (vol. 2) #21, he was seen robbing a bank, leading to a reluctant confrontation with [[Roy Harper (comics)|Red Arrow]] and [[Hawkgirl]]. It was stated in this issue that in the context of the [[DC Universe]], eight years had passed since his arrest in ''Detective'' #274.[[Justice League|''Justice League of America'']] (vol. 2) #21 (July 2008) ===Final Crisis=== {{main|Final Crisis}} He enlisted with [[Libra (DC Comics)|Libra]] and the [[Secret Society of Super Villains]]. As a reward for joining him, Libra promised him power and his heart's desire: "revenge against the Martian Manhunter." Following the events of ''[[Salvation Run]],'' the Martian Manhunter was released from his imprisonment on Cygnus 4019 by Libra at the behest of the Human Flame. Preaching about granting the Society's wildest dreams, Libra stabs the Manhunter with his flaming staff while the Human Flame looks on, his wish having been the first granted by Libra. He films the murder to post on the internet later. While dying, Martian Manhunter telepathically attacked the super villains present with visions of their deaths by their arch-rivals with [[Vandal Savage]] imagining being killed by Manhunter himself. However, the Human Flame is ignored and cowers from the side.''Final Crisis'' #1 (July 2008) The Human Flame is given a new upgraded suit by Libra. The helmet Libra shoves onto Human Flame's head emits the [[Anti-Life Equation]] turning Human Flame into a mindless drone known as a [[Justifiers|Justifier]]. Libra even used the Human Flame amongst other Justifiers to persuade [[Lex Luthor]] to swear an allegiance to [[Darkseid]] or be turned into a Justifier.''Final Crisis'' #3 (September 2008) The Human Flame was among the Justifiers under Lex Luthor's control that were fighting the [[Female Furies]].''Final Crisis'' #7 (March 2009) In the limited series ''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'', it is revealed that the Human Flame had a wife and child, but was divorced. The Human Flame tries to hide while pursued by the Kyrgyzstani Mafia for stealing a cache of money, the villains that Libra enslaved during the Final Crisis, and the Justice League members [[John Stewart (comics)|John Stewart]] and [[Firestorm (comics)|Firestorm]].''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #1 (May 2009) However, his costume is badly damaged during a fight with the mob, and the Human Flame seeks out [[Heat Wave (comics)|Heat Wave]], hoping to purchase one of the latter's signature flamethrower guns. Heat Wave refuses, denouncing him as "pathetic", and gives him a harsh beating. Wounded and unable to afford health care, the Human Flame turns to [[General Immortus]] who turns him over to [[Professor Milo]]. Milo fixes his injuries, and adds cybernetic parts, adding strength and invulnerability, and implanted flamethrowers in his chest, mouth and arms. However, to ensure the Human Flame's loyalty, Immortus has his flamethrowers rigged to cause intense pain whenever he uses them, and orders him to kill Immortus' foe, N-Emy (whom General Immortus blamed for stealing something from him).''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #2 (June 2009) The Human Flame later attempts some freelance jobs, stealing from a bank with the help of [[Seductress (comics)|Seductress]] (one of the augmented henchmen and lover of Immortus himself) and swaying her to his side. However, he's quickly discovered and charged with treason by Milo and Immortus, who try to shut down his powers with a remote control. With Seductress rushing again to his aid, the Human Flame is able to escape destroying the remote but injuring himself in the process.''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #3 (July 2009) However, Human Flame discovers that his new cyborg body has uncanny recuperative abilities that fix the broken jaw suffered during his escape. He fights his former allies successfully, killing them all until Immortus shuts down his powers with a secondary, wireless remote. The Human Flame then regains his powers by sheer will (even the augmented powers), badly burning Immortus. He then tortures Professor Milo to get further augmentations to put him on par with the Justice League and everyone else wanting vengeance against him. Milo sends him to [[S.T.A.R. Labs]] to get himself infused with atomic energy in a new experimental process. There, Human Flame and Seductress are attacked by a ''Hyper-Griffin'',''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #4 (August 2009) thus alerting S.T.A.R.'s security (actually one lone scientist) who agrees to give Human Flame the energy infusion to dispatch the Hyper-Griffin. However, the energy infusion is temporary unless Human Flame can reach a nearby nuclear power plant and bathe in its energies, even though he risks death and a deadly [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdown]]. Despite the risks, he leaves Seductress behind and dupes John Stewart into dunking him in the main reactor. As a result, the nuclear plant is engulfed in a fiery explosion.''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #5 (September 2009) Despite the magnitude of the explosion, so powerful that the assembled heroes barely manage to contain it with their maximum efforts, Flame emerges as a fiery, radioactive being, in a molten approximation of a human body, able to increase his mass and density. Calling himself the ''Inhuman Flame'', he rampages through the city until he increases his mass to such a degree that he becomes basically immobile. Realizing that the Flame, in his quest for power, hadn't even taken into account the idea of becoming "smaller," Firestorm, Red Tornado, and John Stewart take him to outer space, tethered to heat-dispersing rod to sap his thermic-based powers. As a final revenge, and to add insult to injury, Stewart creates a cell-phone construct and takes a photo of the captive Human Flame, stressing the similarities to Martian Manhunter's fate.''Final Crisis Aftermath: Run!'' #6 (October 2009) ==Powers and abilities== When he first appears, Human Flame has no powers, but wears a costume with twelve flame throwing nozzles on the chest. As a part of the ''Run'' series, he is shown being turned into a [[cyborg]] with an enhanced physique, partial body armor and a series of flame-spewing nozzles implanted in his chest, belly, face, mouth and hands. He further enhances his body by an experimental radioactive infusion process: as a result he gains a [[metahuman]] body composed of molten material, able to increase his mass and density at will and radiate high temperature radiations. In this new form he's shown to be unable, whether due to a physical limitation or simply because he is incapable of thinking that way, to reduce his increased mass, becoming in a short while a behemoth so heavy and dense that he loses the ability to move. Throughout his attempt to escape the heroes hunting him, he was represented as an incompetent crook who gets lucky because nobody expects anything of him, allowing him to evade capture as they cannot predict his methods, although his fixation on acquiring more power and anger at his own view of life's mistreatment of him eventually allow the heroes to catch up with him. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{comicbookdb|type=character|id=19394|title=Human Flame}} * [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=16706 FINAL CRISIS FLASHBACK: Libra & Human Flame], [[Comic Book Resources]], June 5, 2008 * [[DCDatabase:Michael Miller (New Earth)|Human Flame]] at the DC Database Project {{Martian Manhunter}} [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1959]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:DC Comics characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional murderers]] [[Category:Fictional characters with fire or heat abilities]]

{{Use British English|date=April 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = James Paul Moody |image = James_Paul_Moody.jpg |birth_date = 21 August 1887 |birth_place = [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|1912|04|15|1887|08|21|df=yes}} |death_place = {{RMS|Titanic}} (sunk), [[Atlantic Ocean]] |occupation = RMS ''Titanic''{{'}}s Sixth Officer}}
'''James Paul Moody''' (21 August 1887 – 15 April 1912) was the Sixth Officer of the {{RMS|Titanic}} and the only junior officer of the ship to die in the disaster.
Born in England, he received a prestigious education and served the [[White Star Line]] aboard the luxurious [[RMS Oceanic (1899)|RMS ''Oceanic'']].
When ''Titanic'' struck the iceberg, he was on watch on the bridge alongside First Officer [[William McMaster Murdoch]] when the ship hit an iceberg. He helped thereafter loading the lifeboats. Despite repeated invitations of his colleagues, he refused to board a boat and died in the sinking.
==Early life== James Paul Moody was born in [[Scarborough, England]] on 21 August 1887, the youngest of four children born to solicitor John Henry Moody and his wife Evelyn Louis Lammin. Moody's grandfather and namesake, John James Paul Moody, had been a prominent local figure. Moody attended the Rosebery House School before joining [[HMS Conway (school ship)|HMS ''Conway'']] as a cadet in 1902.<ref>{{cite web|title=James Paul Moody|url=http://www.scarboroughcivicsociety.org.uk/James-Paul-Moody.php|website=www.scarboroughcivicsociety.org.uk|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> His two years in the ship, 1902-1903, counted as one years' sea time towards his Board of Trade Second Mate's Certification.
== Career == In 1904 he joined the William Thomas Line's ''Boadicea'' as an apprentice, and endured an horrific, storm-troubled voyage to New York, in which one of his fellow apprentices was driven to suicide.<ref>{{Cite web|title = All the Horrors Seem to Happen at Night|url = http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/all-the-horrors-seem-to-happen-at-night.html|website = Encyclopedia Titanica|access-date = 2016-02-08|first = Inger|last = Sheil}}</ref>
After attaining his Second Mate's Certification, Moody went into steam and sailed in cargo and early oil-tankers, eventually attaining his First Mate's Certificate. After very briefly attending the King Edward VII Nautical School in 1910, a nautical "cram" school preparing officers for their Board of Trade examinations, he successfully obtained his Ordinary Master's Certification, and in August 1911 joined the White Star Line's [[RMS Oceanic (1899)|''Oceanic'']] as her Sixth Officer.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Paul Anthony|title=The British Isles a Trivia gazetteer|date=2012|publisher=Summersdale Publishers|location=Chichester|isbn=978-0-85765-827-2|page=227}}</ref> In March 1912 he received word that he was to be assigned to {{RMS|Titanic}} as her Sixth Officer. Moody was somewhat reluctant to accept the assignment as he had hoped to spend a summer on the Atlantic aboard the ''Oceanic'', after having endured a harsh winter, and was also hoping to take leave. His request for leave was denied.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Titanic Valour: The Life of Fifth Officer Harold Lowe|last = Sheil|first = Inger|publisher = The History Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780752477701|location = |pages = }}</ref>
==RMS ''Titanic''== Along with the other junior officers, Moody received a message in March 1912 ordering him to report to White Star's [[Liverpool]] offices on 26 March. From there he travelled to board ''Titanic'' at the [[Harland & Wolff]] yard in [[Belfast]]. ''Titanic'' then sailed for [[Southampton]] to take on passengers. Moody's service as Sixth Officer earned him about $37 a month, although he was allowed his own cabin as compensation for his small salary.
On ''Titanic''{{'}}s sailing day, 10 April, Moody assisted, among other things, in aiding Fifth Officer [[Harold Lowe]] in lowering two of the starboard lifeboats to satisfy the Board of Trade that ''Titanic'' met safety standards. He was also in charge of closing the last gangway, and most likely saved the lives of six crewmen who arrived too late to board by turning them away. Once the ship had put to sea, Moody stood the 4–5 <small>PM</small> watch and both 8–12 watches, which meant that he was on watch with [[Chief mate|First Officer]] [[William McMaster Murdoch|William Murdoch]] and Fourth Officer [[Joseph Boxhall]] when the ''Titanic'' struck an iceberg at 11:40 <small>PM</small> on 14 April. After spotting the iceberg, lookout [[Frederick Fleet]] rang the warning bell three times and phoned the bridge. It was Moody who answered the call, asking, "What do you see?" Fleet replied, "Iceberg, right ahead!".<ref name=":SN:">{{cite news|title=Titanic owners wanted money to return body of Scarborough hero James Moody|url=https://www.thescarboroughnews.co.uk/news/titanic-owners-wanted-money-to-return-body-of-scarborough-hero-james-moody-1-7226729|accessdate=28 November 2017|work=The Scarborough News|date=24 April 2015}}</ref>
In the ensuing evacuation, Moody helped in the loading of Lifeboats No. 9, 12, 13, 14, and 16. While loading No. 14, Fifth Officer Lowe remarked that an officer should man the lifeboat.<ref>{{cite news|title=Titanic letter praises heroic man|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/humber/4508741.stm|accessdate=28 November 2017|work=BBC News|date=3 May 2005}}</ref> While the lower-ranked Moody would traditionally have been given this task, he deferred to Lowe. It was a decision that would seal his fate. Moody went to the starboard side and gave Murdoch a hand until the water had come on the deck. Moody was last seen by the ship's lamp trimmer, Samuel Hemming, on top of the officers' quarters trying to launch Collapsible A, an emergency lifeboat, just a few minutes before the final sinking.<ref>[http://www.titanicinquiry.org/USInq/AmInq07Hemming01.php Testimony of Samuel Hemming] at Titanic inquiry.com</ref> Lightoller also said; "Mr. Moody must have been standing quite close to me at the same time. He was on top of the quarters clearing away the collapsible boat on the starboard side, whilst Mr. Murdoch was working at the falls. If that is so, we were all practically in the water together."<ref>[http://www.titanicinquiry.org/BOTInq/BOTInq12Lightoller09.php Testimony of Charles Herbert Lightoller]</ref>
Moody was 24 at the time of his death. His body was never recovered. He was the only junior officer on the Titanic to die in the sinking.<ref name=":SN:" />
A monument in Woodland Cemetery, Scarborough, commemorates Moody's sacrifice on the ''Titanic'' with the Biblical quote, "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends." (see {{bibleverse||John|15:13}})
He is also commemorated by a Blue Heritage Plaque at 17 Granville Road Scarborough, the house where he was born<ref>{{Cite web|title = James Paul Moody blue plaque in Scarborough|url = http://www.blueplaqueplaces.co.uk/james-paul-moody-blue-plaque-in-scarborough-10390|website = www.blueplaqueplaces.co.uk|access-date = 2016-02-08|first = Good|last = Stuff}}</ref> and a commemorative plaque in St Martin's Church in Scarborough.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Penfold|first1=Phil|title=God's house of wonders on Scarborough's south Cliff|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/god-s-house-of-wonders-on-scarborough-s-south-cliff-1-8215085|accessdate=28 November 2017|work=The Yorkshire Post|date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
He is also commemorated by a brass altar set presented by his aunt, Hannah Mountain, to the church of [[St Augustine of Hippo Grimsby|St Augustine of Hippo]] in Grimsby.
==Portrayals== * Michael Bryant (1958) — ''[[A Night to Remember (1958 film)|A Night to Remember]]'' (British film) *Edward Fletcher (1997) (''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'') *[[Jonathan Howard (actor)|Jonathan Howard]] (2012) (''[[Titanic (2012 miniseries)|Titanic]]'') (TV series/4 episodes)

{{other people||John Fitzalan (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} '''John FitzAlan (D' Arundel), 1st Baron Arundel''' (c. 1348 – 16 December 1379) was a [[Lord Marshal of England|Lord Marshal]] or [[Marshal of England]].
== Lineage ==
He was born in [[Etchingham]], [[Sussex]], [[England]] to [[Richard Fitzalan, 10th Earl of Arundel]] and his second wife [[Eleanor of Lancaster]] (Eleanor Plantagenet). His brother was [[Thomas Arundel]], Archbishop of Canterbury. His sister was [[Joan Fitzalan]], Countess of Hereford.
== High office ==
[[File:betchworth.castle.jpg|thumbnail|right|Betchworth Castle]]
John was appointed [[Lord Marshal of England]] by [[Richard II of England]] in 1377, and summoned to the [[House of Lords]] on 4 August 1377, by writ directed ''Johanni de Arundell''. He served as Lord Marshal until 1379.
On 26 July 1379<ref>[http://www.castleuk.net/castle_lists_south/187/betchworth.html Betchworth Castle Betchworth Park Golf Course Brockham Leatherhead Mole Valley Surrey England English<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.gatehouse-gazetteer.info/LOC/13790726.html Betchworth Castle Licence to Crenellate<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> he was given licence to [[crenellate]] (i.e., permission to fortify) a stone castle on the site of an 11th-century earthwork fortress in Surrey. Over the years since then the structure was rebuilt and remodelled and its remains are now known as [[Betchworth Castle]].
== Naval victory ==
Being in command of a naval expedition in aid to the [[Duke of Brittany]], he defeated the French fleet off the coast of [[Cornwall]].
== Death at sea ==
Commanding a force with the purpose of bringing relief to the [[Duke of Brittany]], Sir John was compelled to wait for stronger winds. During this wait he decided to take refuge in a nunnery, where his men "took no notice of the sanctity of the place and... violently assaulted and raped"<ref name="Walsingham">Thomas Walsingham, "Chronica Maiora"</ref> those they found inside. Further to this Sir John "allowed his men to ransack the countryside as they liked and to impoverish the people".<ref name="Walsingham" /> When the force eventually set out to sea, carrying with them goods stolen from a nearby church and under a pronouncement of excommunication from the wronged priests, the expedition was caught in a storm. [[Thomas Walsingham]] reports that during the panic of the storm, Sir John murdered those of his men who refused to make for shore for fear of being shipwrecked upon the rocks. Subsequently, after safely arriving on an island off the Irish coast, Sir John and his boat captain were swept back into the sea and drowned.<ref name="Walsingham" />
According to [[Thomas Walsingham]]'s story, FitzAlan's men profaned a convent at or near [[Southampton]], and abducted many of its occupants. The fleet was then pursued by a violent tempest, when the wretched nuns who had been carried off were thrown overboard to lighten the ships. The vessels were, however, wrecked on the Irish coast, near [[Scariff]] according to some authorities, but at [[Cape Clear Island]] according to others. Sir John Arundell, together with his esquires, and other men of high birth, were drowned, and twenty-five ships were lost with most of their crews. [[Froissart]]'s account of the event differs essentially from Walsingham's, in the omission of the story of the desecration of the convent.
== Burial ==
He was buried in [[Lewes]], Sussex.
He was also an ancestor of the poet, [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]].
== Marriage and children ==
On 17 February 1358, FitzAlan married [[Eleanor Maltravers, 2nd Baroness Maltravers|Eleanor Maltravers]] (Mautravers) (1345 – 10 January 1404/1406), daughter of [[John Maltravers]] and Gwenthin. They had at least five children (some references list more):
*Joan FitzAlan (D' Arundel) (c. 1360 – 1 September 1404. She married first [[William de Brien]] (no issue) and secondly [[Sir William de Echingham]].<ref>Richardson, D. ''Plantagenet Ancestry: A Study in Colonial And Medieval Families, 2nd Edition'', 2011 (via [https://books.google.com/books?id=kjme027UeagC&pg=PA676&lpg=PA676&dq=william+de+echingham&source=bl&ots=quHiFzZali&sig=yWCdEsqmv3fYaRccJQeV4yUeFMU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uAd7UP3BPMniqgHLyoHQBg&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false books.google.com] pg 676</ref> *[[John FitzAlan, 2nd Baron Arundel]] (3 November 1364 – 14 August 1390), who married [[Elizabeth le Despenser]]. *Richard FitzAlan (c. 1366 – 3 June 1419). His daughter Joan married Thomas Willoughby of Parham, a grandson of Alayne FitzAlan, daughter of [[Edmund_FitzAlan,_9th_Earl_of_Arundel|Edmund Fitzalan, 8th (or 9th) Earl of Arundel.]] *Sir [[William Arundel]] (c. 1369 – 1400). He was a [[List of Knights and Ladies of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]]. *Margaret (1372-7 July 1439) married [[William de Ros, 6th Baron de Ros]] of Hamlake and had descendants
== Ancestry == {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1 = '''John FitzAlan, 1st Baron Arundel''' | 2 = [[Richard Fitzalan, 10th Earl of Arundel]] | 3 = [[Eleanor of Lancaster]] | 4 = [[Edmund Fitzalan, 9th Earl of Arundel]] | 5 = [[Alice de Warenne]] | 6 = [[Henry, 3rd Earl of Lancaster]] | 7 = [[Maud Chaworth]] | 8 = [[Richard Fitzalan, 8th Earl of Arundel]] | 9 = [[Alice of Saluzzo]] | 10= William de Warenne | 11= Joan de Vere | 12= [[Edmund Crouchback, 1st Earl of Lancaster]] | 13= [[Blanche of Artois]] | 14= Sir Patrick de Chaworth, Lord of Kidwelly | 15= [[Isabella de Beauchamp]] | 16= [[John Fitzalan, 7th Earl of Arundel]] | 17= Isabella Mortimer | 18= [[Thomas I of Saluzzo]] | 19= Luigia di Ceva | 20= [[John de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey]] | 21= [[Alice le Brun de Lusignan]] | 22= [[Robert de Vere, 5th Earl of Oxford]] | 23= Alice de Sanford | 24= [[Henry III of England]] | 25= [[Eleanor of Provence]] | 26= [[Robert I of Artois]] | 27= [[Matilda of Brabant]] | 28= Patrick de Chaworth | 29= Hawise de Londres | 30= [[William de Beauchamp, 9th Earl of Warwick]] | 31= [[Maud FitzJohn]] }}

{{Infobox person | name = Livia Medullina | image = Livia Medullina.jpg | caption = Livia Medullina from "[[Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum]]" | birth_name = Livia Medullina Camilla | birth_date = 4 BCE | death_date = 10 (aged 16) | known_for = Fiancee of [[Claudius]] | father = [[M. Furius Camillus (consul of 8 AD)|M. Furius Camillus]] | relatives = [[Lucius Arruntius Camillus Scribonianus]] }}
'''Livia Medullina Camilla''' (fl. 1st century) was the second fiancee of the future Emperor [[Claudius]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Date of the Inscription of Claudius on the Arch of Ticinum |first=Meriwether |last=Stuart |journal=[[American Journal of Archaeology]] |volume=40 |issue=3 |date=July 1936 |pages=314-322 |publisher=[[Archaeological Institute of America]] |doi=10.2307/498692 |jstor=498692}}</ref> She was the daughter of [[M. Furius Camillus (consul of 8 AD)|M. Furius Camillus]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Syme |first=Ronald |author-link=Ronald Syme |title=The Roman Revolution |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=F5ebGZNzSUIC&pg=PA553 |publisher=[[OUP Oxford]] |date=8 August 2002 |page=553 |isbn=9780192803207}}</ref> the consul of 8 AD, who was a close friend of the Emperor [[Tiberius]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Pettinger |first=Andrew |author-link=Andrew Pettinger |title=The Republic in Danger: Drusus Libo and the Succession of Tiberius |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=-ynivDfkESQC&pg=PA230 |publisher=[[OUP Oxford]] |date=24 May 2012 |page=230 |isbn=9780199601745}}</ref> Her brother was [[Lucius Arruntius Camillus Scribonianus|L. Arruntius Camillus Scribonianus]],<ref>{{cite journal |title=Calpurnius Siculus and the Claudian Civil War |first=T. P. |last=Wiseman |author-link=T. P. Wiseman |journal=[[The Journal of Roman Studies]] |volume=72 |year=1982 |pages=57-67 |publisher=[[Society for the Promotion of Roman Studies]] |doi=10.2307/299116 |jstor=299116}}</ref> who served in 32 AD as consul along with [[Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus (consul 32)|Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus]] and had been adopted by [[Lucius Arruntius the Younger]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Cooley |first=Alison |author-link=Alison Cooley |title=The Cambridge Manual of Latin Epigraphy |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=3JRKRl9uT2IC&pg=PA460 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |date=13 September 2012 |page=460 |isbn=9780521840262}}</ref>
She was betrothed to Claudius sometime after his first engagement to his relative [[Aemilia Lepida (fiancee of Claudius)|Aemilia Lepida]] was broken by [[Augustus]] in 8 AD,<ref>{{cite book |last=Levick |first=Barbara |author-link=Barbara Levick |title=Tiberius the Politician |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=47CCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA38 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |date=13 July 2003 |page=38 |isbn=9781134603794}}</ref> due to the disgrace of Aemilia's parents.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kershaw |first=Stephen P. |title=A Brief History of the Roman Empire |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=ET2eBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT85 |publisher=[[Hachette UK]] |date=20 June 2013 |page=85 |isbn=9781780330495}}</ref> Tiberius probably pushed for the new betrothal in order to reward his friend with a connection to the imperial family. The betrothal of Medullina and Claudius is confirmed outside the written records by an extant inscription erected by Medullina's [[pedagogue]]. The dedication is to "Medullina Camilli f. Ti Claudi Neronis Germanici sponsa (Medullina, daughter of Camillus, betrothed of Ti. Claudius Nero Germanicus)."
[[Suetonius]] in ''[[Lives of the Twelve Caesars]]'' states that Medullina unexpectedly fell [[Illness|ill]] and died on the day of her wedding to Claudius,<ref>{{cite book |last=Mudd |first=Mary |title=I, Livia: The Counterfeit Criminal. the Story of a Much Maligned Woman |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=seI0lCAa9w0C&pg=PA338 |publisher=[[Trafford Publishing]] |year=2005 |page=338 |isbn=9781412046060}}</ref> possibly in 9 or 10 AD.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Tiberius Claudius Drusus († AD 20), Son of Claudius and Urgulanilla |first=David L. |last=Vagi |journal=American Journal of Numismatics |volume=22 |year=2010 |pages=81-92 |publisher=[[American Numismatic Society]] |jstor=43580457 |url=http://numismatics.org/store/ajn22/}}</ref>
Medullina's brother Scribonianus was the instigator of the first major [[coup d'etat]] attempt of Claudius' reign, while governor of [[Dalmatia]] in 42 AD.
==In literature==
{{in popular culture|date=November 2018}} *Livia Medullina is referred to in [[Robert Graves]]' novel [[I, Claudius]] as Medullina Camilla; she is depicted as an early love of Claudius who is able to look past his infirmities. Against [[Livia Drusilla]]'s wishes Claudius is permitted to marry Camilla by [[Germanicus]] and [[Augustus]], but is robbed of happiness on the day of their engagement as she is assassinated for an unrelated vendetta against Camilla's uncle.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *[[Barbara Levick|Levick, Barbara]]. '''Claudius.''' Yale University Press. New Haven. *Stuart, M. "The Date of the Inscription of Claudius on the Arch of Ticinum" ''Am. J. Arch.'' 40 (1936). 314-322. *Suetonius '''The Twelve Caesars''' ''Life of Claudius''

[[Image:Deherain-Narbonne-Lara.jpg|thumb|250px|Louis Marie Jacques Amalric, comte de Narbonne-Lara. Portrait by [[Herminie Déhérain]]]] '''Louis Marie Jacques Amalric, comte de Narbonne-Lara''' (17, 23 or 24 August 1755 – 17 November 1813) was a [[French people|French]] [[nobleman]], [[soldier]] and [[diplomat]].{{cite book|chapter-url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=whBIAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA27|year=1836|page=27|chapter=Narbonne-Lara|title=Dictionnaire historique|volume=15|author=Feller, François-Xavier}} ==Birth and early life== He was born at [[Colorno]], in the [[Duchy of Parma]]. His mother was [[Françoise de Chalus]] ([[Baptism|bap.]] [[Château de Châlus-Chabrol]], [[Châlus]], [[Haute-Vienne]], 24 February 1734 - Paris, 7 July 1821, daughter of Gabriel de Châlus, seigneur de Sansac,Chateau of Sansac, in [[Beaulieu-sur-Sonnette]]. and Claire Gérault de Solages), one of the [[ladies-in-waiting]] of [[Louise Élisabeth of France|Elizabeth, Duchess of Parma]] and [[Chamberlain (office)|Chamberlain]]-Major of [[Princess Marie Adélaïde of France]].
Her husband was a nobleman of [[Spanish people|Spanish]] descent [[Don (honorific)|Don]] Jean François, 1er duc de Narbonne-Lara [[Grandee#Spain|Grandee of Spain 1st Class]], [[Lieutenant General]] of the [[French Army|Army]], Commander in Name of the King of the [[Diocese]]s of [[Castres]], [[Albi]] and [[Lavaur, Tarn|Lavaur]], 1st [[Gentleman]] of the House of H.R.H. the [[Philip, Duke of Parma|Duke of Parma]] ([[Aubiac, Lot-et-Garonne]], 27 December 1718 - 12 August 1806), son of François de Narbonne-Lara, seigneur d' Aubiac, and second wife Olympie Angélique de Goth. They married 10 July 1749, and had an older son Philippe, the 2e duc de Narbonne-Lara, without issue,."the son of Very High and Very Powerful Lord, ''Monseigneur'' Jean François, comte de Narbonne-Lara, [[Grandee#Spain|Grandee of Spain 1st Class]], [[Lieutenant General]] of the [[French Army|Army]], Commander in Name of the King of the [[Diocese]]s of [[Castres]], [[Albi]] and [[Lavaur, Tarn|Lavaur]], 1st [[Gentleman]] of the House of H.R.H. the [[Philip, Duke of Parma|Duke of Parma]]; and his wife the Very High and Very Powerful Lady ''Madame'' Françoise de Châlus", duchesse de Narbonne-Lara, [[Chamberlain (office)|Chamberlain]]-Major of ''Madame'' [[Princess Marie Adélaïde of France|Marie Adélaide of France]] (daughter of [[Louis XV]])
However, it is alleged that [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]] himself was the real father. The coevals attribute the count's paternity to the King of France Louis XV for, according to documents of the Military Archive, the comte Jean François de Narbonne-Lara had been wounded 8 years earlier in the [[War of the Austrian Succession]] (1747) becoming from that moment on unable of having any offspring. The [[baptism]] of Louis, comte de Narbonne-Lara is another indication of that paternity."On 25 of August of 1755, received the baptism at the Chapel of the King, from the Very High and Very Powerful Lord, ''Monseigneur'' [[Charles-Antoine de La Roche-Aymon]], [[Archbishop of Narbonne|Archbishop-Primate of Narbonne]], [[President]] of the [[French States-General|States-Generals]] of the [[Province]] of [[Languedoc]], [[Commander#Military and chivalric orders|Commander]] of the [[Order of the Holy Spirit]]. The [[wikt:godfather|Godfather]] was the Most High and Most powerful [[Louis XVI of France|Prince Louis Auguste of France, Duke of Berry]], and the [[wikt:godmother|Godmother]] the Most High and Most Powerful Princess ''Madame'' [[Princess Marie Adélaïde of France|Marie Adélaïde of France]]." His wife became thus the King's [[Mistress (lover)|mistress]], and not only his name was also Louis but also his countemporaries always remarked about the similarities between Louis and the King. He was brought up at [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] with the Princesses of France. His education was princely, inclined mostly towards the [[Classical studies]] and a rigid military formation; he frequented the main [[Court (royal)|Courts]] of [[Europe]], where he was able to familiarize with the foreign languages ([[German language|German]] and [[English language|English]]), which also contributed to his diplomatic formation. He was made [[Colonel]] of the [[French Army|Army]] at the age of twenty-five. ==Marriage and issue== He married Marie Adélaïde (sometimes Adélaïde Marie) de Montholon ([[Mâcon]], 11 or 16 October 1767 - 1848), [[Lady]] of ''Madame'' [[Princess Victoire of France|Victoire of France]], daughter of Louis XV, on 16 April 1782 at Paris, France, with whom he had two daughters.[http://www.thepeerage.com/p8717.htm thePeerage.com] She was the daughter of Nicolas de Montholon (son of Pierre de Montholon and Marguerite Baron, married on 11 June 1711) and Marguerite Fournier de la Chapelle (daughter of Charles Fournier de la Chapelle and Marie Louise Dureau). Their daughters were: * Louise Amable Rion Françoise de Narbonne-Lara ([[Nice]], 25 May 1786 - [[Lisbon]], 28 March 1849), [[Dame (title)|Dame]] of Honour of Her Majesty Queen [[Mary II of Portugal|Mary II]] (with right to the Grandeess of Spain for being representative of her paternal uncle the 2e duc de Narbonne-Lara), who married at [[Agen]] on 17 February 1806 the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] of [[Dutch people|Dutch]] descent [[Hermano José Braamcamp de Almeida Castelo-Branco, 1st Count of Sobral|Hermano José Braamcamp de Almeida Castelo-Branco, 5th Lord, 2nd Baron, 1st Viscount and 1st Count of Sobral]] (16 September 1775 - Lisbon, 2 February 1846), and had two daughters * Marie Adélaïde Charlotte de Narbonne-Lara ([[Belleville (commune)|Belleville]], 11 May 1790 - [[Champgrenon]], 31 May 1856), who married at Agen on 7 March 1808 [[Claude-Philibert Barthelot, comte de Rambuteau]] (Mâcon, 9 November 1781 - [[Château de Rambuteau]], 11 April 1869), and had two daughters Out of wedlock he had by Jeanne Pitrot-Verteil one son: * Louis Jean Amalric de Narbonne-Lara, born in [[Paris]], unmarried and without issue And by [[Louise Contat|Louise-Françoise Contat]] (16 June 1760 - 9 March 1813), [[actress]] with the [[Comédie-Française]], one daughter: * Louise Amalrique Bathilde Isidore Contat de Narbonne-Lara ([[Saint Pierre de Chaillot]], Paris, 21 September 1788 - ?), who married in Paris on 2 December 1811 Dutch Jan Frederik Abbema, born in [[Amsterdam]] on 13 June 1773, and had one son: ** Émile, vicomte d' Abbéma, who had an only daughter by his wife Henriette Anne d' Astoin: *** Louise Abbéma ([[Étampes]], 30 October 1853 - Paris, 4 August 1927), unmarried and without issuehttp://www.geneall.net/F/per_page.php?id=15939 ==Early career== He is found in 1785 as a Colonel of the Army and Honorary [[Chamberlain (office)|Chamberlain]] of Princess ''Madame'' Marie Adélaïde of France. In 1786 he was the [[Commander]] of an [[Infantry]] [[Regiment]], and remained in that post until the evenings of the [[French Revolution]]. ==French Revolution== His [[Liberalism|liberal]] ideas soon made him be one of the first inscribed in the Club de Valois, where the [[Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Duke of Orléans]] presided. He was afterwards appointed Commander of the [[National Guard (France)|National Guard]] in [[Franche-Comté]]. His friendship with [[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord|Talleyrand]] brought him an appointment to command a special guard, composed of the most disciplined soldiers of the National Guard of [[Paris]]. The comte de Narbonne-Lara always maintained his fidelity towards the King; a true idealist, he hoped for a [[Constitutional Monarchy]]. He became [[maréchal de camp]] in 1791, and, through the influence of [[Madame de Staël]], was appointed [[List of Defense Ministers of France|Minister of War]] of [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]]. In this office he tried at all cost to impose his constitutional project, helped by the [[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord|Bishop of Autun]], [[Baumetz]] and [[Isaac René Guy le Chapelier|Chapelier]]. But he showed incapacity in this post, and gave in his resignation. Despite his efforts, he did not carry his point, for in March 1792 the King, moved by intrigues and by the intransigence of those who surrounded him, thought right to dismiss him from that Ministry. His resignation was the result of his disagreements with the [[Feuillant (political group)|Feuillants]] on the question of foreign war. Narbonne-Lara and his friends hoped to bring on the war with Austria, by which they hoped to restore the prestige of the monarchy.The Cambridge Modern History, [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924070596832/cu31924070596832_djvu.txt Volume VIII: The French Revolution, Cambridge, 1904 (full text)] Narbonne-Lara made an alliance with the [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette|Marquis de Lafayette]], but their schemes were defeated. After his resignation, he joined the Army of the North and, in May 1792, he was elevated to [[Lieutenant General]] of the Army. After less than six months from his dismissal, the French Monarchy was agonizing, the French Republic was proclaimed and the Royal Family was incarcerated. Later, Narbonne actually incurred suspicion as a Feuillant. The comte de Narbonne-Lara also had on him a prison warrant. Due to this, and also to questions about his policy at the war office, he managed to seek refuge at the [[Embassy]] of [[Sweden]], emigrated after [[10 August (French Revolution)|10 August 1792]], and later evaded to [[London]] and from there to Germany, having visited [[Kingdom of Great Britain|England]], [[Switzerland]] and [[Holy Roman Empire|Germany]]. During the [[French Consulate|Consulate]], his friends Talleyrand and [[Joseph Fouché|Fouché]] managed to remove his name from the list of the wanted, and returned to France in 1801, where he was retired with the patent of [[Divisional General]]. ==In Napoleon's service== In 1809 [[Napoleon]] remembered him and called him into his service. Brilliant, cultivated and perfectly aware of the uses of the Ancien Régime, ''persona grata'' with the main Courts of Europe, skilled diplomat and military, he was the ideal person to be at his side. As such, he was reintegrated and re-entered the [[French Army|Army]] with his former post of Lieutenant General and appointed [[Governor]] of [[Győr|Raab]], with the command of the whole part of [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungary]] occupied by the [[Grande Armée|imperial troops]]. After signed the peace with Hungary, he was appointed [[Divisional General]] Commander of the 4th Military Division in [[Trieste]]. In that same year of 1809 he was sent to [[Vienna]] to arrange the marriage of the Emperor with [[Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma|Archduchess Marie Louise]]. In 1810 he was subsequently appointed [[Minister Plenipotentiary]] in [[Kingdom of Bavaria|Bavaria]] at [[Munich]], next to King [[Maximilian I Joseph of Bavaria|Maximilian I]], whom he knew very well before the Revolution, and in 1811 ''[[aide-de-camp]]'' to Napoleon. He was created an Officer of the [[Legion of Honour]] and [[Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of Saint Hubert (Bavarian)|Order of Saint Hubert]]. In 1812 he went on diplomatic mission to [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]]; this mission had the purpose of ascertaining King [[Frederick William III of Prussia|Frederick William III]] towards his attitude in case [[First French Empire|France]] went to war with [[Russian Empire|Russia]]. In returning to Paris, de Narbonne-Lara advised Napoleon not to invade Russia, but his advice was not followed; and so he reassumed his place in the Imperial Army on the Russian border. When he arrived there, he was sent by Napoleon to the city of [[Wilna]], where the [[Emperor of Russia|Tsar]] was; the comte de Narbonne-Lara was the bearer of an ultimatum, to which [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] categorically refused. The tragic outcome of the [[French Invasion of Russia|Russian Campaign]] did not minimize the action of the [[Officer (armed forces)|Officers]] of the Imperial Army. Among them, he was outstanding for his military uprightness and exemplary behaviour; in the whirl of the retreat, he appeared dauntless and serene, his presence imposed confidence and respect to the demoralized troops. Mounted on his horse beside the carriage of the defeated Napoleon, he was the personification of the dignity and honour of the ''Ancien Régime''. In 1813 he was appointed and sent as French [[Ambassador]] at Vienna, where he was engaged in an unequal diplomatic duel with [[Klemens von Metternich|Metternich]] during the fateful months that witnessed the defection of Austria from the cause of Napoleon to that of the Allies, to confirm the alliance between France and [[Austrian Empire|Austria]], objective he was not able to fulfill; the Empire had its days cut short. In that same year he was appointed Governor of the stronghold of [[Torgau]] ([[Kingdom of Saxony|Saxony]]), one of the main strategic points for the defense of the Empire. On 17 November 1813, after reviewing the troops on horse, he died of [[typhus]].This garrison suffered an outbreak of [[typhus]], and of the 26,000 men that constituted it, 17,000 died of the epidemic. His aide-de-camp, [[Captain (land)|Captain]] comte de Rohan-Chabot, brought his heart back to France, and afterwards the name of the comte de Narbonne-Lara was inscribed on the east side of the [[Arc de Triomphe]]. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |title=Putative Ancestors of Louis, comte de Narbonne-Lara |collapsed=yes|align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. The '''management by wandering around''' ('''MBWA'''), also '''management by walking around''',<ref name="BD"> "What is management by walking around (MBWA)", BusinessDictionary.com, 2010, webpage: [http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/management-by-walking-around-MBWA.html BD-def-MBWA]. </ref> refers to a style of business [[management]] which involves managers wandering around, in an unstructured manner, through the workplace(s), at random, to check with employees, equipment, or on the status of ongoing work.<ref name=BD/> The emphasis is on the word ''wandering'' as an unplanned movement within a workplace, rather than a plan where employees expect a visit from managers at more systematic, pre-approved or scheduled times.
The expected benefit is that a manager, by [[random sampling]] of events or employee discussions, is more likely to facilitate improvements to the morale, sense of organizational purpose, productivity and [[total quality management]] of the organization, as compared to remaining in a specific office area and waiting for employees, or the delivery of status [[report]]s, to arrive there, as events warrant in the workplace.
==Similarities==
"Management by wandering around" very similar to the Japanese [[gemba|gemba walk]] method developed at [[Toyota]].
== History == The origin of the term has been traced to executives at the company [[Hewlett-Packard]] for management practices in the 1970s.<ref> This was most particularly attributed to John Blocker, division manager at HP's New Jersey Division in Rockaway. Those of us working there though... really knew what he was doing... he was walking around the facility... BUMMING CIGARETTES. Still... it was an excellent way to keep your finger on the pulse of the activity, morale, etc., in the division and the "style" spread throughout the company over time. ''Leadership Elements: A Guide to Building Trust'', Mike Mears, 2009, 364 pages, p.51, Google Books link: [https://books.google.com/books?id=zTDElD68jT0C&pg=PA51&dq=Management+By+Wandering+Around%22&hl=en BooksG-TOC-51]. </ref> However, the general concept of managers making spontaneous visits to employees in the workplace has been a common practice in some other companies as well. Also, the management consultants [[Tom Peters]] and [[Robert H. Waterman]] had used the term in their 1982 book ''[[In Search of Excellence: Lessons from America's Best-Run Companies]]''.<ref> ''In Search of Excellence'', [[Tom Peters]] and [[Robert H. Waterman]], 1982, 2004 (360 pages), p.289, web: [https://books.google.com/books?id=knzNIfmU2F0C&pg=PA289&dq=Management+By+Wandering+Around%22&hl=en BooksG-FOC-289]. </ref> Historian [[Stephen B. Oates]] asserts<ref> With Malice Toward None: The Life of Abraham Lincoln'', Stephen B. Oates, 1977, 544 pages: </ref> that Abraham Lincoln invented the management style by informally inspecting the Union Army troops in the early part of the [[American Civil War]].
== See also == * [[W. Edwards Deming]] * [[Total quality management]]

'''Paul Otieno Imbaya''' (1973 – 25 December 2007), better known for his stage name '''Mighty King Kong''', was a [[reggae]] musician from [[Kenya]]. He was born in Ugenya, [[Siaya District]].
As a young child he suffered a severe [[polio]] and was disabled from the waist down. He went to Ambira Primary School, but dropped out at Standard Six following the death of his father. He moved to [[Kisumu]] city where he became a [[Street children|street kid]] and [[beggar]].<ref name="nationfm">{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaudio.com/96-4NATION/feature8.html |title=Rags to Records - The reggae musician who started off as a street beggar in Kisumu |last=Karuoya |first=Njoki |date=2000 |website=[[Nation FM]] |access-date=20 June 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000510170051/http://www.nationaudio.com/96-4NATION/feature8.html |archive-date=10 May 2000}}</ref>
In 1993 he moved to [[Nairobi]]. With the assistance of DJ Stone, a local [[deejay]] whom he had met in Kisumu, he was able to perform at Nairobi clubs on weekly basis.<ref name="nationfm"/>
Few years later he moved to [[Mombasa]] and performed with bands like Them Mushrooms and Pressmen. Later on, he moved to [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] to perform with the popular Simba Ngoma band. In Kampala he earned enough money to records his first album. He went back to Nairobi where his album, titled ''Ladies Choice'', was produced by Maurice Oyando of the Next Level studios.<ref name="nationfm"/> It was released in June 1999. His second album, ''Cinderella'' was released in 2001, again by Next Level studios.
His third album, ''Return of the King'', was released in 2004. However, Mighty King Kong publicly blamed its contract of being exploitative.<ref name="bounce">{{cite news |url=http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=60&newsid=100876 |title=Mighty King Kong now poised to bounce back |last=Orido |first=Fred |date=23 June 2007 |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]]}} {{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eastandard.net/archives/cl/mags/pulse/articles.php?articleid=1143965210&date=23/2/2007 |title=Gone with the lyrics |last=Nyanga |first=Caroline |date=22 February 2007 |newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)|The Standard]] |access-date=20 June 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229205412/http://www.eastandard.net/archives/cl/mags/pulse/articles.php?articleid=1143965210&date=23%2F2%2F2007 |archive-date=29 December 2007}}</ref> In 2007, he released a compilation album "The Best of King Kong".<ref name=bounce/>
Outside Kenya, he performed in [[Germany]], [[Netherlands]] and [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesnews.co.ke/19mar06/magazine/magazine6.html |title=From grass to grace |date=19 March 2006 |newspaper=[[Kenya Times]]}} {{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Above all, he was a die-hard supporter of Raila Odinga's ODM political movement which had promised to nominate him to the next parliament to represent the disabled persons of Kenya. He was seen dressed in orange colours as a sign of firm commitment to the party in his last days.
==Death== He died on Christmas Day, 2007 at the age of 34, after being poisoned (as attributed in the local newspapers). He was transported to Kenyatta National Hospital in [[Nairobi]], where he died as he was being treated. He was survived by his widow, Jackline Ouma,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=1&newsid=113372 |title=Curtain falls on singer Mighty King Kong |last=Orido |first=Fred |date=26 December 2007 |newspaper=Daily Nation}} {{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and a child.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979516&cid=159 |title='Mighty' King Kong passes on |last=Adero |first=Brian |date=26 December 2007 |newspaper=The Standard |access-date=20 June 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229205422/http://eastandard.net/news/?id=1143979516&cid=159 |archive-date=29 December 2007}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Pieter Hintjens | image = Pieter_Hintjens_at_EuroPython2014.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1962|12|03}} | birth_place = [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2016|10|04|1962|12|03}} | death_place = | death_cause = [[Voluntary euthanasia]]<ref name="The last tweet" /> after diagnosis of terminal [[bile duct cancer]]<ref name="A Protocol For Dying" /> | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | occupation = CEO, software developer, author | known_for = | website = {{URL|http://hintjens.com}} }} '''Pieter Hintjens''' (3 December 1962 – 4 October 2016) was a Belgian [[software developer]], author, and past president of the [[Foundation for a Free Information Infrastructure]] (FFII), an association that fights against [[software patent]]s. In 2007, he was nominated one of the "50 most influential people in [[Intellectual property|IP]]" by Managing Intellectual Property magazine.
==Biography== Hintjens was born in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] in 1962 and grew up in [[East Africa]].<ref>{{cite web |publisher=The Hintjens' Wiki |url=http://hintjens.com/pieter-hintjens:cv:personal-details |title=Pieter Hintjens |accessdate=2 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.digistan.org/member:pieter-hintjens|title=Pieter Hintjens - members.digistan.org|website=members.digistan.org|access-date=2016-09-17}}</ref>
Hintjens served as CEO and chief software designer for iMatix, a firm that produced [[free software]] applications, such as the [[ZeroMQ]] high performance message [[Library (computing)|library]], the [[OpenAMQ]] AMQP [[messaging]] service, Libero,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://imatix-legacy.github.io/libero/lrintr.htm|title=Introduction to Libero|access-date=2016-10-04}}</ref> the GSL code generator,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/imatix/gsl|title=GSL/4.1 - a Universal Code Generator|access-date=2016-10-04}}</ref> and the [[Xitami]] web server.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://imatix-legacy.github.io/|title=Welcome to iMatix|website=imatix-legacy.github.io|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref>
He was active in [[open standard]]s development, being the author of the original [[Advanced Message Queuing Protocol]] (AMQP), a founder of the [[Digital Standards Organization]], and the editor of the [[RestMS]] web messaging protocol.<ref name="restms">RestMS.org, [http://www.restms.org/spec:2 RestMS - a RESTful Messaging Service]</ref> RestMS is developed using a ''peer-to-peer, share-alike, branch and merge'' model (COSS) developed by Hintjens and others for the Digital Standards Organization in 2008.<ref name="coss">{{cite web |publisher=Digistan |url=http://www.digistan.org/spec:1 |title=Consensus-Oriented Specification System}}</ref>
He was CEO of [[Wikidot]] Inc., one of the fastest growing [[wikifarm]]s, until February 2010.
In 2010 Hintjens was diagnosed with [[Cholangiocarcinoma|bile duct cancer]], which was successfully surgically removed.<ref name="Five Years, Five Wishes">{{cite web | url=http://hintjens.com/blog:109 | title=Five Years, Five Wishes | date=2015-12-10 | accessdate=2016-04-22}}</ref> However, in April 2016, it returned and he was diagnosed with terminal [[cholangiocarcinoma]].<ref name="A Protocol For Dying">{{cite web | url=http://hintjens.com/blog:115 | title=A Protocol For Dying | date=2016-04-21 | accessdate=2016-04-22}}</ref> Hintjens underwent [[voluntary euthanasia]] on 4 October 2016.<ref name="The last tweet">{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/hintjens/status/783254242052206592 | title=I'm choosing euthanasia etd 1pm. I have no last words. | date=2016-10-04 | accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
== ZeroMQ == While in his position as iMatix CEO, Hintjens founded the [[ZeroMQ]] software project together with Martin Sustrik. ZeroMQ is a high-performance asynchronous messaging library aimed at use in scalable distributed or concurrent applications.
In November 2013, Hintjens announced [[EdgeNet]], a project building upon ZeroMQ for mesh networks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/edgenet/x/5209896|title=edgenet|publisher=}}</ref> EdgeNet aims to build a secure, [[Anonymity on the Internet|anonymous]] [[peer-to-peer]] alternative to the internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cultureandempire.com/edgenet.html|title=Culture & Empire · GitBook|publisher=}}</ref> Hintjens also authored several ZeroMQ projects, such as CZMQ, zproto, and Malamute.
==Views== In October 2007, Hintjens warned that after [[mortgage]]s and [[consumer debt]], [[patent]]s were a third [[economic bubble]] waiting to damage the global economy, writing: "House prices fall and bad debt shakes the financial markets across the US and Europe. Bankers look nervously at their portfolios of consumer debt and mortgages. But some analysts say that it's patents, not houses or loans, that will tip the global financial market into crisis".<ref name="crisis">Digital Majority, [http://www.digitalmajority.org/forum/t-21772/will-the-patent-system-trigger-financial-collapse-in-2008 "Will the patent system trigger financial collapse in 2008?'']</ref>
Hintjens was also owner and principal author of ''The Devil's [[Wiki]]'', which defines a ''patent'' as "A medieval economic tool by which politicians attempt to stimulate trade and wealth by banning innovation and competition in crucial areas of technology".<ref name="patent">{{cite web |publisher=Devil's Wiki |url=http://wiki.hintjens.com/wiki:patent |title=Patent}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * "Confessions of a Necromancer", 2016 * "Social Architecture", 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hintjens.com/books|title=Books by Pieter Hintjens |website=hintjens.com|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> * "The Psychopath Code", 2015 * "ZeroMQ: Messaging for Many Applications", ''[[O'Reilly Media]]'', 2013 * "Culture and Empire: Digital Revolution", 2013 * "Code Connected Volume 1", 2013 * "Scalable C", unfinished<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gitbook.com/book/hintjens/scalable-c/details|title=Scalable C (in progress) |website=GitBook|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://hintjens.com Hintjens.com official website] * [http://wiki.hintjens.com/ Devil's Wiki] * [http://gca.org/attend/2001_conferences/europe_2001/bios/3.htm gca.org] * [http://heironymouscoward.blogspot.com/ heironymouscoward.blogspot.com] * [http://www.freesoftwaremagazine.com/files/nodes/1254/1254.pdf Free Software magazine Issue 12] * [http://capsoff.org/ CapsOff Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081101011415/http://www.openamq.org/ OpenAMQ AMQP messaging system] * [http://hintjens.com/blog:125 Confessions of a Necromancer - Hintjens.com] * [http://hintjens.com/blog:115 "A Protocol for Dying" - Hintjens.com] * [http://sdtimes.com/sd-times-blog-zeromq-founder-pieter-hintjens-dies/ "ZeroMQ founder Pieter Hintjens dies" - SD Times blog]

"Passionate Goodbye") is a 2013 [[South Korea]]n film directed by Nam Taek-soo, starring [[F.T. Island]] lead vocalist [[Lee Hong-ki]] as an [[Korean pop idol|idol star]] who learns to cope with his past and rediscovers music during community work at a hospice for terminally ill patients.{{cite web|last=Hong|first=Lucia|title=FTIsland Lee Hong-ki to make big screen debut|url=http://www.tenasia.com/ftisland-lee-hong-ki-to-make-big-screen-debut/|work=TenAsia|accessdate=2014-04-06|date=30 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407084611/http://www.tenasia.com/ftisland-lee-hong-ki-to-make-big-screen-debut/|archivedate=7 April 2014|df=}}{{cite web|last=Sunwoo|first=Carla|title=Not all is grim when the reaper pays a visit|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2972026|work=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|accessdate=2014-04-04|date=24 May 2013}} ==Plot== Chung-ui is a famous [[K-pop|Korean pop]] star with a temper. After he beats up a man at a night club, he is sentenced to do [[community service]] at a [[hospice]] for [[terminal illness|terminally ill]] patients. The reluctant young man first hates his chores and dislikes the people around him, but as he gets to know their stories, he becomes attached to them. The hospice struggles with funding, leading to a possible close-down, so the hospice in-house band, The Phoenix Band decides to apply to a talent show on television. For this, they need an original song, so they ask Chung-ui to help them. The singer refuses at first, then tries to use the opportunity to reduce his sentence days. He ends up seriously changing his mind about music, his behavior and grows to accept his mother's death, while helping the patients achieve their dreams.
